headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Kirby Corporation 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Sterling Adlakha. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Kirby Corporation 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Sterling Adlakha. Please go ahead.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carrie. Thank you, everyone for joining us this morning. With me today are Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski, Kirby's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
componenttext: Thank you, Carrie. Thank you, everyone for joining us this morning. With me today are Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski, Kirby's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at www.kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under Financial Highlights. Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015 filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. With that, I'll now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sterling, and good morning. Yesterday afternoon, we announced first quarter earnings of $0.71 per share, including severance charges of approximately $0.06 per share versus our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.85 per share. That compares with $1.0
componenttext:
Thank you, Sterling, and good morning. Yesterday afternoon, we announced first quarter earnings of $0.71 per share, including severance charges of approximately $0.06 per share versus our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.85 per share. That compares with $1.09 per share reported first quarter last year. And the marine tank barge utilization during the first quarter remained in the 90% to 95% range. The supply overhang from barges cleaned out of crude oil service and put into other trades over the past 12 to 18 months continue to have some impact on pricing. However, we think the trend of barge cleaning out of crude oil service into clean service has slowed significantly and we believe that industry utilization levels have modestly improved. Additionally, we have not seen an increase in inland tank barge -- in the inland tank barge order book for 2016, which is now at low levels. Should the trend -- trends that we've seen in April continue for another couple of months, our outlook for this business will continue to improve. 
In the coastal sector of our business, utilization remained stable, with coastal tank barge utilization in high 80s to low 90% range. Market is in relative balance even with the additional spot exposure. Average pricing on contract renewals of the coastal equipment increased during the quarter. A part of this increase was the result of price adjustments of legacy contracts, which were below market rates. Also influencing our results in this business is the amount of equipment trading in the spot market, which has idle time exposure. In our land-based Diesel Engine Services business, market conditions deteriorated further than we envisioned when we provided guidance in January. There's not been many positive signals in the oil service market. There's been accelerating decline in U.S. oil production, which has led to cannibalization -- or at least cannibalization to existing U.S. pressure pumping capacity, which should create future demand. However, without more tangible improvement, the prudent thing to do is to aggressively reduce cost in this business. 
Market has simply been far worse for longer than I think anyone in the market anticipated, as evidenced by recent earnings and CapEx revision -- revisions by several large oil service companies. In the marine power generation business, our marine diesel engine business, the oil -- oil service market, which services the Gulf of Mexico remain depressed and we experienced customer deferrals of major maintenance projects throughout all of our marine engine service locations during the quarter. This is not unusual when you get in this kind of environment. This broad impact on our marine market speaks to the uncertainty of not only the oil service business, but also the dry cargo market that the inland side of the business services. And at some respects, the general economy. In summary, we find ourselves in the midst of a very challenging environment in both our marine and diesel engine businesses. At the same time, we have seen some encouraging trends in our Marine markets, particularly the inland market where pricing seems more stabilize. I'll now turn the call over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with a quick comment on our recent cost savings actions and then move to first quarter results across our businesses. Our cost-cutting efforts included a reduction in force that was implemented in F
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with a quick comment on our recent cost savings actions and then move to first quarter results across our businesses. Our cost-cutting efforts included a reduction in force that was implemented in February. We reduced headcount and corporate staff, marines shore-side staff and diesel engine personnel. These reductions led to severance cost of approximately $0.06 a share. While the staffing reduction was the most visible cost-cutting actions during the quarter, we have several teams dedicate to streamlining of our cost structure across the company and in improving customer service. It is our belief that as conditions across our markets improve, we will be positioned to improve market share in each of our businesses while simultaneously improving profitability. 
Turning now to a summary of first quarter results. In the marine transportation segment, our inland marine barge demand saw some modest sequential improvement as utilization stayed in the 90% to 95% range throughout the quarter. During the quarter, high wind and fog impacted operations along the Gulf Coast and high water on the Mississippi River system led to the delays and added horsepower requirements. The direct cost associated with these challenges were partially mitigated by contract losses that protect us from navigation delays, particularly as it relates to high water. On a fairly positive note, we think the number of barges transitioning from crude oil into other services slowed dramatically. We believe the industry fleet wide number of barges include services really just under 175, virtually unchanged from earlier in the year. The industry has absorbed a large number of barges from both new construction and from displaced crude movements during the past year to 18 months and is very close to tightly balanced. 
Nevertheless, pricing on our inland Marine transportation term contracts that renewed during the first quarter were down in the single-digit range. Average contract pricing was skewed lower by repricing of some longer-term contracts. Excluding these contracts, a more representative indication of pricing on inland contract renewals was down in the low-single-digit percent range on a year-over-year basis. 
Spot contract rates were roughly in line with contract rates during the quarter and were flat sequentially with the 2015 fourth quarter. However, in April, we did see some firming in the spot market from market close. In the inland marine market, we continued to see growth, modest growth and demand for petrochemicals and refined products transportation, with crude oil demand relatively flat with the 2015 fourth quarter. The black oil market, meaning heated products excluding crude oil was weak throughout the quarter, largely due to commodity price volatility, but utilization our Blackwell fleet recovered toward the end of the quarter and into April. 
In our coastal marine transportation segment, demand for the coast was transportation refine products, black oil and petrochemicals remain consistent with the 2015 fourth quarter and tank barge utilization continue to be relatively strong. With respect to pricing term contracts that renewed during the first quarter increased by double-digit percentage on average. However, this pricing was skewed by the renewal of a couple of small legacy contracts with rates that were significantly below market levels. 
Excluding those contract renewals, renewals on coastal equipment contracts were essentially flat. 
In our Diesel Engine Services segment them as Joe mentioned, our marine diesel and power generation markets experienced widespread deferrals of major maintenance projects across all of our marine diesel engine operating regions. While there is some possibility that these deferrals could lead to higher business levels later this year, our assumption is that, that will not happen, particularly if the inland dry cargo barge and Gulf of Mexico oil service markets do not improve. 
In our land-based Diesel Engine Services market, our ability to maintain break-even profit levels with our current staffing was dependent on maintaining a steady level of parts and components sales and a modest amount of remanufacturing activity, a view was regarded from close coordination with our major customers. However, as the first quarter progress, orders for parts and components declined precipitously. Projected spending levels from our major customers for the full year 2016 for parts and components sales were revised down by over 50%. 
On the service side of the business, the year began with some incrementally positive indicators as customers requested to remanufacture portions of their fleets with the opportunity to remanufacture the larger portions of their fleets as the year progressed. However, financial stress and uncertainty around consolidation opportunities among our customer base has resulted in almost all remanufacturing being placed on hold through the near term. As we work through these challenges, an await an inevitable improvement in the market, we want to strike a balance between maintaining the capability to respond to demand when the market turns and a cost structure that is appropriate for the current market. The volatility of the market and opaqueness of the outlook make this difficult. So we thought it prudent to assume these tough conditions persists through the remainder of this year and consequently, we reflected that in our forecast. I will now turn the call over to Andy to provide some detailed financial information before I finish up with a more detailed discussion of the outlook.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and good morning. In the 2016 first quarter, marine transportation segment declined 10%, and operating income declined 28% as compared with the 2015 first quarter. This decline in revenue was primarily due to a 38% decline in the average
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and good morning. In the 2016 first quarter, marine transportation segment declined 10%, and operating income declined 28% as compared with the 2015 first quarter. This decline in revenue was primarily due to a 38% decline in the average cost of marine diesel fuel, lower inland marine contract pricing and an increase in available spot market days for some of our offshore marine equipment. The marine transportation segment's operating margin was 18.4% compared with 22.9% for the 2015 first quarter. The inland sector contributed approximately 2/3 of marine transportation revenue during the 2016 first quarter. 
Long-term inland marine transportation contracts, those contracts with a year with a term of 1 year or longer in duration, contributed approximately 80% of revenue, with 55% attributable to time charters and 45% from teh fragment contracts. As David mentioned from, our utilization was consistently above 90% throughout the quarter and the inland sector generated operating margin in the low 20% range for the quarter. 
In the coastal sector, utilization during the quarter was in the high 80% to low 90% range. The trend of our customers electing to source coastal equipment through the spot market versus renewing existing term contracts continued in the first quarter, as we saw the percentage of coastal revenue under term contracts dropped slightly from the 2015 fourth quarter to 78%. The first quarter operating margin for the coastal sector was in the low- to mid-teens. 
As mentioned in the press release last night, we incurred an approximate $5.6 million or $0.06 per share in severance expenses during the quarter. Of this amount, approximately $0.03 per share was in our inland marine business, approximately $0.01 per share is in our coastal marine business and approximately $0.01 in our marine and power generation diesel businesses, with the remainder split between the land-based diesel engine business and the Kirby Corporate Office. 
Turning now to our marine construction and retirement plans. During the 2016 first quarter, we took delivery of 3 new tank barges, and we're total of 16 barges. The net result was a reduction of 13 tank barges to our inland tank barge fleet while approximately 278,000 barrels of capacity. Also during the quarter, we committed to build an additional 4 of 30,000 barrels tank barges for delivery in 2016 to be our existing fleet needs and attractive pricing. For the remaining 9 months of the year, we expect to take delivery of these 4 inland tank barges and to retire or return an additional 18 barges with 235,000 barrels of capacity. 
On a net basis, before giving effect to the additions from the SQL fleet, we expect to end 2016 with approximately 17.5 million barrels of capacity, a reduction of approximately 400,000 barrels from the end of 2015. In mid-April, we closed on the acquisition of sea course fleet of 27 30,000-barrel inland tank barges. Additionally, 1 30,000-barrel tank barge and 1 in 1 [ph] tow boat are under construction and are expected to be delivered before the end of the quarter. Including these additions to our inland fleet, we expected to end 2016 with a total of 18.4 million barrels of capacity. 
In the coastal transportation sector, we expect delivery of our second new 185,000-barrel ATB in mid-2016. The first of 2 new 155,000-barrel ATB should also deliver in late 2016. Our second 155,000-barrel ATB and the coastal chemical barge are expected to be completed in 2017. Our 2016 coastal equipment capacity plan includes a single retirement of an 80,000-barrel tank barge in the second quarter. On a net basis, we expect to end the year with 6.3 million barrels of capacity and additional 260,000 barrels from the end of the 2016 first quarter. 
Moving onto our Diesel Engine Services segment. Revenue for the 2016 first quarter declined 52% from the 2015 first quarter and we had an $806,000 operating loss for the segment. This segment operating margin was a negative 1% compared with 5.3% for the 2015 first quarter. The Marine and power generation operations contributed approximately 60% of the Diesel Engine Services revenue in the first quarter, with an operating margin in the low double digits. Our land-based operations contributed roughly 40% of the Diesel Engine Services segment revenue in the first quarter, with a negative operating margin in the high-teens. 
On the corporate side of things, we raised our 2016 capital spending guidance range by $10 million to a range of $230 million to $250 million to account for the additional 4 inland tank barges that we expect to build this year. Our capital spending guidance for the year includes approximately $10 million for the construction of 7 inland tank barges to be delivered in 2016, approximately $100 million in progress payments on new coastal equipment, including 1 185,000-barrel coastal ATB, 2 150,000-barrel coastal ATBs, 2 4,900-horsepower coastal tugboats and a new coastal petrochemical tank barge. The balance of $120 million to $140 million is primarily for capital upgrades and improvements to existing inland and coastal marine equipment and facilities, as well as diesel engine services facilities. In addition to capital spending guidance for the year, we used $88 million in cash in April this year for the purchase of the sea course 30,000-barrel in 1 tank barge fleet. 
During the 2016 first quarter, we continued to execute on our share repurchase authorization, buying approximately 35,000 shares for $1.8 million or $52.53 per share. Stock price, in our estimation, continues to offer compelling long-term value. We will continue to evaluate share repurchases in concert with other capital allocation opportunities. Currently, our unused repurchase authorization is approximately 1.4 million shares. Total debt as of March 31, 2016 was $712 million, a $63 million decrease from December 31, 2015. Our debt-to-cap ratio at March 31 was 23.5% compared with the 25.4% at the end of last year. As of today, our debt stands at $783 million. I will now turn the call back over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 second quarter guidance of $0.65 to $0.75 per share and for the 2016 full year guidance of $2.80 to $3.20 per share. Our guidance for the year reflects our 2016 first quarter GAAP earnings per s
componenttext:
Thank you, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 second quarter guidance of $0.65 to $0.75 per share and for the 2016 full year guidance of $2.80 to $3.20 per share. Our guidance for the year reflects our 2016 first quarter GAAP earnings per share of $0.71, which includes $0.06 per share of severance charges. As we mentioned earlier, the significant change in our outlook is related to the land-based diesel engine business, which we now expect to incur quarterly operating losses for the remainder of the year. With that overview of our -- of the changes to our guidance, let me also briefly address the primary factors in the guidance range for each of our markets. 
In our inland marine transportation market, as mentioned in our press release last night, the inland market showed some tangible signs of improvement in April with utilization improving, particularly for 30,000-barrel tank barges, and competitors spot pricing in the spot market improving from previous month. Refined products and chemical volumes have been strong with the black haul market seeing some renewed strength in April following at the first quarter. While we're encouraged by these developments, we are cautious and extrapolating the impact for the rest of the year. At the low end of our guidance, our guidance factors and spots and contract renewal pricing include declines of low single-digits and tank barge utilization in the high 80s to low 90% range. At the high-end, we are assuming year-over-year pricing stability going forward and utilization in the 90% to 95% range. We are assuming normal seasonal weather patterns for the remainder of the year. 
In the coastal markets, on the high end of guidance, we are expecting flat to slightly higher pricing on contract renewals and utilization in the high 80% range. On the low end, our guidance range contemplates a deterioration in coastal rates with pricing declines on contract renewals in the low single-digit percentage range and utilization in the mid-80% range. For our Diesel Engine Services segment in our land-based sector, although oil prices have improved somewhat, it has not yet translated to an improved outlook. The improvement may come in the second half, but with lower spending levels seen in the first quarter, we felt it prudent to adjust this portion of our quarterly and full year guidance. We will continue to evaluate market conditions and adjust the cost structure as necessary to meet current and projected levels of demand. For the balance -- what must balance the lack of volume in today's market was the outlook for our market recovery as oil prices continue and increase. Where we fall within our guidance range of this year will partly probably hinge on whether we see an improvement in activity in the second half of the year. In our marine, diesel and power generation markets, we expect the weakness in the Gulf of Mexico oil service markets to persist for the entire year. There is some possibility that major maintenance projects deferred by customers in the first quarter could drive better performance later this year. But our business based case assumption is that those deferrals will not lead to firm orders until 2017. So in summary, our balance sheet and cash flow are in great shape, giving us the flexibility to do acquisitions and share repurchases. The Marine business is stable with the inland markets poised for improvement and with the bright outlook for petrochemical volumes. Diesel Engine Services is weak, but with a growing pent-up demand. And in the diesel engine business is, it is not a question of if the markets will come back, but a question of when. Operator, that concludes our prepared remarks. We're now ready to take questions.

Could you give us some updated color on that and may be put some numbers around what your expectations for inland barge growth this year or next year?

componenttext: Yes. Right now, as we look at the orders, and many of the orders for delivery in 2016 were placed last year. We think it's around 100 new barges, but what we don't know is the number of retirements that may occur this year. You heard in Andy's prepared remarks that we're retiring a number of barges. We do believe that some others are going to retire older equipment as well. Also in that number of new barge build that we expect this year, the vast -- well, not the vast majority, but over half are probably 10,000 barrels. And those we know, many of them were placed early in 2015 or in 2015. So kind of a carryover. So it does look reasonably good on the new build additions given that we expect retirements usually to be in the 75 to 150 barges retired a year, sometimes they go north of that.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And my follow-up is on utilization in the inland segment. It seems these are holding better than the coastal segment. What do you think are the primary driver is there? Is that mostly a function of the follow-up in crude Corpus Christi versus the
componenttext: Got you. And my follow-up is on utilization in the inland segment. It seems these are holding better than the coastal segment. What do you think are the primary driver is there? Is that mostly a function of the follow-up in crude Corpus Christi versus the impact coastal markets? Or are there other factors at work there?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, the inland market, what we've seen is basically demand's picked up. The inland market has absorbed a lot of barges in both new builds and return cleaned up barges from crude service that overlap 18 months. And that, as we mentioned, the crude kin
componenttext: Yes. No, the inland market, what we've seen is basically demand's picked up. The inland market has absorbed a lot of barges in both new builds and return cleaned up barges from crude service that overlap 18 months. And that, as we mentioned, the crude kind of -- the number of crude barges being returned is potentially stopped. So with the demand pick-up, the utilization's tightened up and that's what we've been seeing. And you saw our utilization was in the 90% to 95% range for the quarter, which is pretty good. And that's really all about demand. On the coastwise side, demand's relatively imbalanced. It's not a lot different than we're seeing on the inland side.

componenttext: All right. And David, obviously talked a little bit about the spots you're seeing in April. What do you think is driving that? It sounds like a much more demand, but in March, I think we started seeing spot market strengthen a little and that may have been to do some high water barges out of position, lot closers, et cetera. So do you think this movement we're seeing in April is a little bit more real, if you will? And do you think it will continue because of our call last year, we had a little bit of a had baked in the spot market. So maybe talk a little bit about what you're seeing now and why it might be different from last year. Or maybe it's not. .

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Kevin, good question. It's hard to extrapolate 1 month here, but clearly, weather it was a little bit of it, weather sometimes tightens up utilization, but what we felt was what's demand up a little bit here and that there's demand for the spot barges
componenttext: No, Kevin, good question. It's hard to extrapolate 1 month here, but clearly, weather it was a little bit of it, weather sometimes tightens up utilization, but what we felt was what's demand up a little bit here and that there's demand for the spot barges and there's a little bit of the scarcity in the number of available barges because of that additional demand. And so that brought spot pricing off of its lows, which is good to see. But to your point, you don't want -- we don't want to be overly aggressive in extrapolating that. But it's an encouraging sign.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then on the -- looking at the diesel engine business, as a whole, obviously, we know that the pressure points on the land-based side. It now seems like the core business especially may be the offshore business, is a little bit under p
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then on the -- looking at the diesel engine business, as a whole, obviously, we know that the pressure points on the land-based side. It now seems like the core business especially may be the offshore business, is a little bit under pressure. You incurred a modest loss in the quarter. I know you've taken a tremendous amount of cost out of that business. Is there any more do there that gets us in back, kind of break even on consistent basis. And at this point, is it really about having beget some business activity pumping back through there?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's more of the latter, John. We've taken, in the land-based United business, we've taken our headcount from 950 employees around down to in the 300s. So we've taken a lot of cost out. What we're trying to balance is being prepared for the inevitabl
componenttext: Yes. It's more of the latter, John. We've taken, in the land-based United business, we've taken our headcount from 950 employees around down to in the 300s. So we've taken a lot of cost out. What we're trying to balance is being prepared for the inevitable upturn. The amount of pent-up demand for maintenance on fracked equipment is substantial. So you don't want to cut too deep. You got to be able to respond to some customer demand that we believe will be inevitable. So we're trying to balance that. You keep looking at your cost structure every day and we'll continue to do that. We just felt it prudent to kind of take down our estimates on the land-based business. That's the key part of this -- of our guidance change here. It's all about that land business. This didn't feel prudent to forecast, kind of a rebound towards the end of the year at this point, no. Maybe we see it, maybe we don't, but we didn't want to fight it all year long.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Is there 1 macro data point on the land-based side that you look at? I mean, is it the rig count number? I mean, if we were thinking about a, we obviously don't have an opportunity your internal discussions with customers, but if there's that 1
componenttext: All right. Is there 1 macro data point on the land-based side that you look at? I mean, is it the rig count number? I mean, if we were thinking about a, we obviously don't have an opportunity your internal discussions with customers, but if there's that 1 data point, that suggests stabilization or something, is it rig count? What is it that you look for?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, land-based rig counts, probably the most obvious one. Now that said, there are anywhere from 3,500 to 4,000 docks, which is drilled but uncompleted wells. They basically drilled the holes. They just haven't fracked them. So you could get -- with this
componenttext: Yes, land-based rig counts, probably the most obvious one. Now that said, there are anywhere from 3,500 to 4,000 docks, which is drilled but uncompleted wells. They basically drilled the holes. They just haven't fracked them. So you could get -- with this oil price rebound, you could get some of those docks, if you will. They could drive some pressure pumping utilization, which would clearly help our business because we think the state of the pressure pumping fleet is in pretty poor repair. They've been cannibalizing it in some of the cold stack fleets really aren't even operable. So short answer to your question, the rig count's, the most obvious one, but there is this phenomena of drilled but uncompleted wells out there that may give us some advance business before the rig count rebounds.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, in the prepared remarks, and again, on the call, you talked about inland regarding the coastal business that you're just seeing more of the equipment go on to the spot market. And this sounds like it's just on the margin. What do you -- do you have
componenttext: David, in the prepared remarks, and again, on the call, you talked about inland regarding the coastal business that you're just seeing more of the equipment go on to the spot market. And this sounds like it's just on the margin. What do you -- do you have any sort of thoughts about what is driving the unwillingness of customers to sort of take those longer-term charters? And then just get a question I wanted to ask is, when a coastal vessel is in spot, what is a typical duration of the spot voyage?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take that in 2 parts. Well, first, spot voyage can be anywhere from 1 month to 6 months. For us, anything spot is less than a year. So you can have 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months voyages or contracts that we consider spot. But in terms
componenttext: Yes. Let me take that in 2 parts. Well, first, spot voyage can be anywhere from 1 month to 6 months. For us, anything spot is less than a year. So you can have 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months voyages or contracts that we consider spot. But in terms of what we think driving it is there's a number of new builds coming out. And I think customers, given the uncertainty with commodity price volatility and the number of new builds coming out, we're kind of waiting to see they don't feel like they're going to have problem finding equipment. Now that said, as you know, there's a number of barges we think it's over 40 that there are 30 years or older that need to them out in the market and they will come out. It's just -- it's a matter of the timing between the new builds coming in and old barges coming out.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. My follow-up is going to be on the Diesel Engine Services business. componenttext: It's so variable, Greg. I think the issue is what to the cannibalized if they just took the fluid ends off or if they took an engine off and put an engine on on another fracked spread, you -- it would depend. Now if they're just sitting there not maintaining them at all, it could be substantial and you could see north of that $500,000 a unit. Some of them may be very, very small in terms of what it needs to get them back in the operation, but others could be quite substantial. I know that's not answer, Greg, but short answer is probably we don't know, but it's going to vary depending on what they cannibalized.

I mean, we've been hearing that there's varying degrees of what an idle frac spread looks like where some are just left with the actual truck and others were to report some there's 1 or 2 or 3 things maybe take enough so I'm just want to see if you had any more color than that, but anyway, hey guys, thanks for the time.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of follow-ups. First, it's been very helpful when quantifying the exposure and the inland of marine transportation market, how many barges were in the crude oil market. My question is when you look at the coastal business, things are o
componenttext: I just had a couple of follow-ups. First, it's been very helpful when quantifying the exposure and the inland of marine transportation market, how many barges were in the crude oil market. My question is when you look at the coastal business, things are obviously holding in very well there. Can you give us some sort of sense of how many assets or what proportion of your coastal assets are either directly or indirectly involved in the crude oil trade?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, good question. I think coastwise, there were -- it was probably similar to the level of -- in terms of percentages that we saw in the inland side. I think at the market peak coast-wise business had probably 15% of the barge fleet in crude and now
componenttext: Yes. No, good question. I think coastwise, there were -- it was probably similar to the level of -- in terms of percentages that we saw in the inland side. I think at the market peak coast-wise business had probably 15% of the barge fleet in crude and now we think it's less than 5% as well. At our peak, we had probably 10% of our fleet in crude. Now, it's a tiny 2% or so, 2% or 3%. So the coastwise has rationalized. It actually a lot less impact than the inland side. Because you've seen that coastwise has absorbed the larger barges coming out of crude and pricing has been relatively stable and, in fact, up most of last year. So in the coastwise business, it's been tighter, tighter in terms of balance.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gawky. It's very helpful we haven't seen a narrowing pricing differentials are along the Gulf Coast. I was just curious how much more of an impact that can have on you guys business. My second question, my follow-up has to do with the similar theme in tha
componenttext: Gawky. It's very helpful we haven't seen a narrowing pricing differentials are along the Gulf Coast. I was just curious how much more of an impact that can have on you guys business. My second question, my follow-up has to do with the similar theme in that kind of trying to quantify downside exposure on the Diesel Engine Services side. And this might be less quantifiable, but in terms of your guidance changes, do you view kind of your guidance now as far as being yes, this is a concern sink type of a number we're expecting operating losses and so that's really kind of the worst that we think it's going to get or how can you anecdotally describe how you view your interim services point going forward?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is Andy. In terms of our guidance, certainly from the midpoint of our prior range to the midpoint of our current range, in the broadest of strokes, that was due to the severance in the first quarter and then the changes in our outlook for the l
componenttext: Doug, this is Andy. In terms of our guidance, certainly from the midpoint of our prior range to the midpoint of our current range, in the broadest of strokes, that was due to the severance in the first quarter and then the changes in our outlook for the land-based Diesel Engine Services business. From that point, sort of the lower end of our range, I would say, there's some -- an additional modest losses or incrementally modest losses out of that business, but we pretty much taken a pretty dim view for the full year and are not really too willing to bet on the comp too much there.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: David, I wanted to ask about a couple of follow-ups on the coastal side and just how the competitive landscape's changing is more of your equipment spot market and as more of these new builds start to deliver. Is there going to be a significant shift in kind of the upper hierarchy of news in that business and how made that impact kind of the pricing over term contracts, especially that also of the spot market?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think roughly speaking, the order, if you will, of the 15 or so players in the market is going to be roughly the same. I don't think there's going to be a big shift between whose the third largest and the sixth largest. I think everybody's kind of
componenttext: Yes. I think roughly speaking, the order, if you will, of the 15 or so players in the market is going to be roughly the same. I don't think there's going to be a big shift between whose the third largest and the sixth largest. I think everybody's kind of added capacity, kind of in proportion to their fleet size. And so we've added --  we'll have added when we complete the new builds here, we'll have added 5 new barges on a basis of 70, right? So that's kind of proportionate to our size. I think if you look at our competitors have done similar things.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you think the kind of shift to the spot becomes more of a permanent issue with the new capacity coming online or at some point, this kind of normalized do...
componenttext: And do you think the kind of shift to the spot becomes more of a permanent issue with the new capacity coming online or at some point, this kind of normalized do...

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it would normalized and actually, if you go back, as the older capacity comes out, you'll go back to more term. I think this is a transitional time in terms of spot versus contract.
componenttext: I think it would normalized and actually, if you go back, as the older capacity comes out, you'll go back to more term. I think this is a transitional time in terms of spot versus contract.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For my second question, the C-Corp. acquisition look very well-timed and quite interesting too because you've kind of in the market for a couple of years in the inland businesses as values kind of run away and you maintained your discipline. Obviously, C-
componenttext: For my second question, the C-Corp. acquisition look very well-timed and quite interesting too because you've kind of in the market for a couple of years in the inland businesses as values kind of run away and you maintained your discipline. Obviously, C-Corp. wasn't a pure-play in this business and have far more exposure to businesses that have been hammered of late, especially the offshore supply of business. So was this kind of one-off, may be stressed sale and just kind of right place, right time? Or is this kind of foreshadowing now that passive values pulling back to a level where they're tied in your sweet spot, and you can be a little bit more aggressive on the rolling up of the business?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You'd probably have to ask C-Corp. some of those questions, but yes. I wouldn't say it was a stressed sale. I think they're very opportunistic in terms of deploying cash to beating down sectors. So there may be something they're doing. But you should
componenttext: Yes. You'd probably have to ask C-Corp. some of those questions, but yes. I wouldn't say it was a stressed sale. I think they're very opportunistic in terms of deploying cash to beating down sectors. So there may be something they're doing. But you should probably ask them that. From our view, in terms of pricing, given through what we've been going through in the inland market, pricing gets more reasonable price expectations becomes more reasonable and that's a good thing. As you know, John, it's really tough to predict acquisitions. We're always talking to people. There are some people that may have a lot more stress in terms of leverage than others, but predicting that an predicting an acquisition out of that environment is difficult. I think our view is, as you know, just maintain our discipline. People know we'll pay a fair price and we're going to keep our discipline and keep talking to the players and if something happens, that's great. But we're not going to chase things. I do think that given what we've gone through the inland market, things are more reasonable in terms of price expectations.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jack Atkins of Stephens.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the April commentary is certainly very encouraging on the inland side. As you're talking to customers, are they taking notice of that? And at what point do you think that's more positive sort of trend line we've been seeing the last several weeks,
componenttext: I think the April commentary is certainly very encouraging on the inland side. As you're talking to customers, are they taking notice of that? And at what point do you think that's more positive sort of trend line we've been seeing the last several weeks, last month or so could translate into better contractual rate renewals? Do you think that's something a couple of months away? Is it going to be later this year? Just sort of curious how you guys are thinking about the cadence of that.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes,'s it's really difficult to say, Jack. It's hard to extrapolate. A quick look, our customers are some of the most sophisticated companies in the world. So they know what's going on, and they see it. They're probably seeing the same thing that we are s
componenttext: Yes,'s it's really difficult to say, Jack. It's hard to extrapolate. A quick look, our customers are some of the most sophisticated companies in the world. So they know what's going on, and they see it. They're probably seeing the same thing that we are seeing, which is demand. Demand is up a little bit now. Whether that carries through the remainder of the year and grows remains to be seen. It's just really difficult to predict. And so we want to be cautious in extrapolating it. What we do know that the chemical petrochemical build out is continuing. Some -- there's a good number of these petrochemical plants that are well underway in terms of construction. May be some of the volatility has slowed some of them down or, may be even 1 or 2 canceled, but we do see the petrochemical buildout coming '17 and '18, which should add demand. So whether as a short-term inflection point here or not remains to be seen, but the longer-term volume trends are pretty good.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good to hear. And then just a quick follow-up item. With fuel moving back up a little bit here, can you remind us how few will impacts your P&L? Is it more of a pass-through or when you have inflections higher or lower, how does that impact n
componenttext: Okay, that's good to hear. And then just a quick follow-up item. With fuel moving back up a little bit here, can you remind us how few will impacts your P&L? Is it more of a pass-through or when you have inflections higher or lower, how does that impact near-term profitability?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Years, there's a couple of different ways. More in a lot of our businesses, there's a pass-through, Jack. But on some of our contracts, we actually have escalation causes, and this lage about 1 quarter. So what you can see is a little bit of a mismatch be
componenttext: Years, there's a couple of different ways. More in a lot of our businesses, there's a pass-through, Jack. But on some of our contracts, we actually have escalation causes, and this lage about 1 quarter. So what you can see is a little bit of a mismatch between when your revenue gets reset on the contract and when your cost have changed. So as we see that, you can have a little bit of friction. But again, with fuel going up, we would expect that in the second quarter, our cost my rise a little bit ahead of our revenue, which will then reset going into the third quarter.

componenttext: This is Chris Boone on the line Kelly. You guys talked a little bit about retirements need for the register come out. I'm just wondering if you can give us some color if you've seen whether or not your peers have started some of this accelerated retirement that may currently have an operation? And if not yet, what do you think will spur this acceleration that you're looking for?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me talk in terms of the inland side and the coastal side. Go inland, what happens is in the land side, in particular, when you're getting to the inspection cycle and the mandated inspections that have to happen, you bring a barge into the shipya
componenttext: Well, let me talk in terms of the inland side and the coastal side. Go inland, what happens is in the land side, in particular, when you're getting to the inspection cycle and the mandated inspections that have to happen, you bring a barge into the shipyard and you kind of get an estimate on what it takes to extend its life another 5 years and you kind of do the math with the current prices and is a well, does that make sense? Can I get that capital back. And so given what we've gone through here recently, those older barges get harder and harder to justify and that triggers kind of the retirement. We've seen this in past cycles where the retirements get pretty heavy. We kind of expect them to be on the heavier side than they have been for the last couple of years for sure. On the coastwise business, it's -- some of these assets are over 30 years old. I think that count -- last count was 45. We're over 30 years old and in the coastwise environment, that's getting pretty old. And we, Kirby, have retired some of our older assets recently in that space and I think our competitors are going through the same thought process that we are in terms of extending very old coastwise barges. As you know, those are much more expensive than inland barges. So extending their lives is that much more capital. I don't know if that helps with the answer there, Chris.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, absolutely. Appreciate
componenttext: No, absolutely. Appreciate

componenttext: On the coastal side, to the extent that Kirby's causing weakness relative to inland, how much of that is being driven in the crude oil ask for versus lower production in South Texas?

componenttext: Steve, we don't think coastwise is really being impacted by crude. I think most of the crude coastwise moves have migrated out already and that occurred basically through last year while pricing was stabled up. So I think on the coastwise side, what's been upsetting the crude oil last year was refined products continuing to rise. I think you're probably seen some of the macro statistics with vehicle miles driven going up on some other positive trends there. So I don't think crude has been a factor on the coastwise business as much as it has been in inland.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, it's hard to say. There are a handful, probably 6, 7 MLPs that have marine assets. I would view some of them, the marine assets are not core to their business. And but others may view it as core. It's hard to say clearly when the high-yield markets closed off to them that may or made them think about it a little and I don't in terms of issuing equity, it wasn't the best time to do it. I think it varies by the different MLPs. Some are very strong, some are smaller and less able to weather this. We'll see, as we've said in the past, if it's really difficult to predict acquisition possibilities. Clearly, we stand ready to take any assets they view as noncore.

componenttext: Yes. Well, typically, in our capital deployment, we tend to be in the market when other people aren't. But yes, I wouldn't read a lot into the CapEx. We had an opportunity to buy a few barges at a pretty decent price. They fit into our retirement plan as we phased out some equipment. It's kind of our normal operating mode, if you will.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Just to add on a little bit there. I mean, if you added up, we're adding 7 barges this year through capital expenditures in the inland side, and we're retiring 31. So again, with the trend that we think we'll see in the industry this year, probably some retirements and very little building. I think we're right in line with that.

componenttext: Yes. No, weather was there. We saw some fog and high winds and some high water that impacted us throughout the quarter. Some of that was covered. But there was some cost associated with it that's kind of in our numbers. I wouldn't call it something material enough to call out, maybe it was a $0.01 or $0.02, but it's kind of in our numbers.

componenttext: I guess a lot of questions had been asked, so I just like to shift to capital allocation. Obviously, you guys like to do acquisitions first, but relative to debt or share buyback, could you just give a little more color there? headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, our story on this has always been pretty consistent. And we believe that there's a time to look at M&A, there's a time to be building equipment, there's a time to pay down debt and time to buy back shares. We're certainly our capital expendit
componenttext: Yes. I mean, our story on this has always been pretty consistent. And we believe that there's a time to look at M&A, there's a time to be building equipment, there's a time to pay down debt and time to buy back shares. We're certainly our capital expenditure program is pretty limited this year with the exception of what was committed for in the past on the offshore side. We'll still sort of look at all the M&A opportunities that we can. Between that, we'll evaluate where we are in the market and whether or not a share buyback if that time makes sense for us versus debt repayment. We don't generally gives sort of any kind of guidance about, which 1 we're going to do.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think Bill, you're right. What we were trying to get a feel for was there something going on in the economy that it just didn't feel right that the economy was weaker and that inventories were up and trading patterns were a little different, but that seems to have worked itself out. Yes, I think just talking and listening to our customers, inventories are where they need to be given what they're seeing. I think in the ethylene markets, what we're hearing is all positive that's kind of sort itself out. I think clearly, the crude price kind of stabilizing a little bit now and still volatile, but it's kind of a more reasonable range lately has taken some uncertainty out of the system. So yes, that feel we had that maybe something was going on in the economy that we were missing in that that he said we had as it never completely goes away as you know, but it is certainly improved and we feel better about it. And certainly listening to our customers, it's been more positive in the near term.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: I'll be quick. In the inland barge segment, do you have any idea of the percent breakdown across the industry between pet chem time, petroleum products and crude and black or? And are we back in line with the say, more historic norms that were boom and it was these numbers can be at times, but any color on that would be very helpful.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you look at our business, we're probably around 50%. Now this is in total barge business but inland and coastal is around 50% pet chem. But when you look at England, which was your question, our pet chem volumes are around 67%, 68% and bla
componenttext: Yes. I think if you look at our business, we're probably around 50%. Now this is in total barge business but inland and coastal is around 50% pet chem. But when you look at England, which was your question, our pet chem volumes are around 67%, 68% and black oil, which is around 20% and the rest is refined products and chems. So that's us. We're probably stronger in pet chems then most of the industry. I would say the industry is probably south of 50% pet chems.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carrie. Thank you, everyone, for joining us this morning. With me today are: Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski, Kirby's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Offic
componenttext: Thank you, Carrie. Thank you, everyone, for joining us this morning. With me today are: Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski, Kirby's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at www.kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under Financial Highlights. Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015 filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. With that, I'll now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Sterling, and good morning. Yesterday afternoon, we announced first quarter earnings of $0.71 per share, including severance charges of approximately $0.06 per share versus our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.85 per share. That compares wit
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Sterling, and good morning. Yesterday afternoon, we announced first quarter earnings of $0.71 per share, including severance charges of approximately $0.06 per share versus our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.85 per share. That compares with $1.09 per share reported first quarter last year. Inland marine tank barge utilization during the first quarter remained in the 90% to 95% range. The supply overhang from barges cleaned out of crude oil service and put into other trades over the past 12 to 18 months continue to have some impact on pricing. However, we think the trend of barge cleaning out of crude oil service into clean service has slowed significantly and we believe that industry utilization levels have modestly improved. Additionally, we have not seen an increase in inland tank barge -- in the inland tank barge order book for 2016, which is now at low levels. Should the trend -- trends that we've seen in April continue for another couple of months, our outlook for this business will continue to improve. 
In the coastal sector of our business, utilization remained stable, with coastal tank barge utilization in the high 80s to low 90% range. Market is in relative balance, even with the additional spot exposure. Average pricing on contract renewals of the coastal equipment increased during the quarter. A part of this increase was the result of price adjustments in legacy contracts, which were below market rates. Also influencing our results in this business is the amount of equipment trading in the spot market, which has idle time exposure. In our land-based Diesel Engine Services business, market conditions deteriorated further than we envisioned when we provided guidance in January. There have not been many positive signals in the oil service market. There's been an accelerating decline in U.S. oil production, which has led to cannibalization -- or at least some cannibalization to existing U.S. pressure pumping capacity, which should create future demand. However, without more tangible improvement, the prudent thing to do is to aggressively reduce cost in this business. 
Market has simply been far worse for longer than I think anyone in the market anticipated, as evidenced by recent earnings and CapEx revision -- revisions by several large oil service companies. In the marine power generation business, our marine diesel engine business, the oil -- oil service market, which services the Gulf of Mexico remain depressed and we experienced customer deferrals of major maintenance projects throughout all of our marine engine service locations during the quarter. This is not unusual when you get in this kind of environment. This broad impact on our marine market speaks to the uncertainty of not only the oil service business, but also the dry cargo market that the inland side of the business services. And in some respects, the general economy. In summary, we find ourselves in the midst of a very challenging environment in both our marine and diesel engine businesses. At the same time, we have seen some encouraging trends in our Marine markets, particularly the inland market where pricing seems to have stabilized. I'll now turn the call over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with a quick comment on our recent cost savings actions and then move to first quarter results across our businesses. Our cost-cutting efforts included a reduction in force that was implemented in F
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with a quick comment on our recent cost savings actions and then move to first quarter results across our businesses. Our cost-cutting efforts included a reduction in force that was implemented in February. We reduced headcount and corporate staff, marine shore-side staff and diesel engine personnel. These reductions led to severance costs of approximately $0.06 a share. While the staffing reduction was the most visible cost-cutting action during the quarter, we have several teams dedicated to the streamlining of our cost structure across the company and in improving customer service. It is our belief that as conditions across our markets improve, we will be positioned to improve market share in each of our businesses while simultaneously improving profitability. 
Turning now to a summary of first quarter results. In the marine transportation segment, our inland marine barge demand saw some modest sequential improvement as utilization stayed in the 90% to 95% range throughout the quarter. During the quarter, high wind and fog impacted operations along the Gulf Coast and high water on the Mississippi River system led to the delays and added horsepower requirements. The direct cost associated with these challenges were partially mitigated by contract clauses that protect us from navigation delays, particularly as it relates to high water. On a clearly positive note, we think the number of barges transitioning from crude oil into other services slowed dramatically. We believe the industry fleet-wide number of barges in crude services, currently just under 175, virtually unchanged from earlier in the year. The industry has absorbed a large number of barges from both new construction and from displaced crude movements during the past year to 18 months, and is very close to tightly balanced. 
Nevertheless, pricing on our inland Marine transportation term contracts that renewed during the first quarter were down in the single-digit range. Average contract pricing was skewed lower by repricing of some longer-term contracts. Excluding these contracts, a more representative indication of pricing on inland contract renewals was down in the low-single-digit percent range on a year-over-year basis. 
Spot contract rates were roughly in line with contract rates during the quarter and were flat sequentially with the 2015 fourth quarter. However, in April, we did see some firming in the spot market from market lows. In the inland marine market, we continued to see growth, modest growth and demand for petrochemicals and refined products transportation, with crude oil demand relatively flat with the 2015 fourth quarter. The black oil market, meaning heated products, excluding crude oil, was weak throughout the quarter, largely due to commodity price volatility, but utilization in our Blackwell fleet recovered toward the end of the quarter and into April. 
In our coastal marine transportation segment, demand for the coast was transportation of refined products, black oil and petrochemicals remain consistent with the 2015 fourth quarter and tank barge utilization continued to be relatively strong. With respect to pricing term contracts that renewed during the first quarter increased by a double-digit percentage on average. However, this pricing was skewed by the renewal of a couple of small legacy contracts with rates that were significantly below market levels. 
Excluding those contract renewals, renewals on coastal equipment contracts were essentially flat. 
In our Diesel Engine Services segment, as Joe mentioned, our marine diesel and power generation markets experienced widespread deferrals of major maintenance projects across all of our marine diesel engine operating regions. While there is some possibility that these deferrals could lead to higher business levels later this year, our assumption is that, that will not happen, particularly if the inland dry cargo barge and Gulf of Mexico oil service markets do not improve. 
In our land-based Diesel Engine Services market, our ability to maintain break-even profit levels with our current staffing was dependent on maintaining a steady level of parts and component sales and a modest amount of remanufacturing activity, a view which we garnered from close coordination with our major customers. However, as the first quarter progressed, orders for parts and components declined precipitously. Projected spending levels from our major customers for the full year 2016 for parts and component sales were revised down by over 50%. 
On the service side of the business, the year began with some incrementally positive indicators, as customers requested to remanufacture portions of their fleets with the opportunity to remanufacture the larger portions of their fleet as the year progressed. However, financial stress and uncertainty around consolidation opportunities among our customer base has resulted in almost all remanufacturing being placed on hold for the near term. As we work through these challenges, and await an inevitable improvement in the market, we want to strike a balance between maintaining the capability to respond to demand when the market turns and a cost structure that is appropriate for the current market. The volatility of the market and opaqueness of the outlook make this difficult. So we thought it prudent to assume these tough conditions persist through the remainder of this year and consequently, we reflected that in our forecast. I will now turn the call over to Andy to provide some detailed financial information before I finish up with a more detailed discussion of the outlook.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and good morning. In the 2016 first quarter, marine transportation segment revenue declined 10%, and operating income declined 28% as compared with the 2015 first quarter. This decline in revenue was primarily due to a 38% decline in the
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and good morning. In the 2016 first quarter, marine transportation segment revenue declined 10%, and operating income declined 28% as compared with the 2015 first quarter. This decline in revenue was primarily due to a 38% decline in the average cost of marine diesel fuel, lower inland marine contract pricing and an increase in available spot market days for some of our offshore marine equipment. The marine transportation segment's operating margin was 18.4% compared with 22.9% for the 2015 first quarter. The inland sector contributed approximately 2/3 of marine transportation revenue during the 2016 first quarter. 
Long-term inland marine transportation contracts, those contracts with a year -- with a term of 1 year or longer in duration, contributed approximately 80% of revenue, with 55% attributable to time charters and 45% from affreightment contracts. As David mentioned, our utilization was consistently above 90% throughout the quarter and the inland sector generated an operating margin in the low 20% range for the quarter. 
In the coastal sector, utilization during the quarter was in the high 80% to low 90% range. The trend of our customers electing to source coastal equipment through the spot market versus renewing existing term contracts continued in the first quarter, as we saw the percentage of coastal revenue under term contracts drop slightly from the 2015 fourth quarter to 78%. The first quarter operating margin for the coastal sector was in the low- to mid-teens. 
As mentioned in the press release last night, we incurred an approximate $5.6 million or $0.06 per share in severance expenses during the quarter. Of this amount, approximately $0.03 per share was in our inland marine business, approximately $0.01 per share is in our coastal marine business and approximately $0.01 in our marine and power generation diesel businesses, with the remainder split between the land-based Diesel Engine business and the Kirby Corporate Office. 
Turning now to our marine construction and retirement plans. During the 2016 first quarter, we took delivery of 3 new tank barges, and we retired a total of 16 barges. The net result was a reduction of 13 tank barges to our inland tank barge fleet, or approximately 278,000 barrels of capacity. Also during the quarter, we committed to build an additional 4 30,000 barrels tank barges for delivery in 2016, to meet our existing fleet needs and attractive pricing. For the remaining 9 months of the year, we expect to take delivery of these 4 inland tank barges and to retire or return an additional 18 barges with 235,000 barrels of capacity. 
On a net basis, before giving effect to the additions from the Seacor fleet, we expect to end 2016 with approximately 17.5 million barrels of capacity, a reduction of approximately 400,000 barrels from the end of 2015. In mid-April, we closed on the acquisition of Seacor's fleet of 27 30,000-barrel inland tank barges. Additionally, 1 30,000-barrel tank barge and 1 inland tow boat are under construction and are expected to be delivered before the end of the quarter. Including these additions to our inland fleet, we expected to end 2016 with a total of 18.4 million barrels of capacity. 
In the coastwise transportation sector, we expect delivery of our second new 185,000-barrel ATB in mid-2016. The first of 2 new 155,000-barrel ATBs should also deliver in late 2016. Our second 155,000-barrel ATB and the coastal chemical barge are expected to be completed in 2017. Our 2016 coastal equipment capacity plan includes a single retirement of an 80,000-barrel tank barge in the second quarter. On a net basis, we expect to end the year with 6.3 million barrels of capacity, an additional 260,000 barrels from the end of the 2016 first quarter. 
Moving on to our Diesel Engine Services segment. Revenue for the 2016 first quarter declined 52% from the 2015 first quarter and we had an $806,000 operating loss for the segment. The segment's operating margin was a negative 1% compared with 5.3% for the 2015 first quarter. The Marine and power generation operations contributed approximately 60% of the Diesel Engine Services revenue in the first quarter, with an operating margin in the low double digits. Our land-based operations contributed roughly 40% of the Diesel Engine Services segment revenue in the first quarter, with a negative operating margin in the high-teens. 
On the corporate side of things, we raised our 2016 capital spending guidance range by $10 million to a range of $230 million to $250 million to account for the additional 4 inland tank barges that we expect to build this year. Our capital spending guidance for the year includes approximately $10 million for the construction of 7 inland tank barges to be delivered in 2016, approximately $100 million in progress payments on new coastal equipment, including 1 185,000-barrel coastal ATB, 2 150,000-barrel coastal ATBs, 2 4,900-horsepower coastal tugboats and a new coastal petrochemical tank barge. The balance of $120 million to $140 million is primarily for capital upgrades and improvements to existing inland and coastal marine equipment and facilities, as well as diesel engine services facilities. In addition to capital spending guidance for the year, we used $88 million in cash in April of this year for the purchase of Seacor's 30,000-barrel inland tank barge fleet. 
During the 2016 first quarter, we continued to execute on our share repurchase authorization, buying approximately 35,000 shares for $1.8 million or $52.53 per share. Stock price, in our estimation, continues to offer compelling long-term value. We will continue to evaluate share repurchases in concert with other capital allocation opportunities. Currently, our unused repurchase authorization is approximately 1.4 million shares. Total debt as of March 31, 2016 was $712 million, a $63 million decrease from December 31, 2015. Our debt-to-cap ratio at March 31 was 23.5% compared with the 25.4% at the end of last year. As of today, our debt stands at $783 million. I will now turn the call back over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 second quarter guidance of $0.65 to $0.75 per share and for the 2016 full year guidance of $2.80 to $3.20 per share. Our guidance for the year reflects our 2016 first quarter GAAP earnings per s
componenttext:
Thank you, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 second quarter guidance of $0.65 to $0.75 per share and for the 2016 full year guidance of $2.80 to $3.20 per share. Our guidance for the year reflects our 2016 first quarter GAAP earnings per share of $0.71, which includes $0.06 per share of severance charges. As we mentioned earlier, the significant change in our outlook is related to the land-based diesel engine business, which we now expect to incur quarterly operating losses for the remainder of the year. With that overview of our -- of the changes to our guidance, let me also briefly address the primary factors in the guidance range for each of our markets. 
In our inland marine transportation market, as mentioned in our press release last night, the inland market showed some tangible signs of improvement in April, with utilization improving, particularly for 30,000-barrel tank barges, and competitor spot pricing in the spot market improving from previous month. Refined products and chemical volumes have been strong, with the black oil market seeing some renewed strength in April following a tough first quarter. While we're encouraged by these developments, we are cautious in extrapolating the impact for the rest of the year. At the low end of our guidance, our guidance factors in spot and contract renewal pricing, includes declines of low single-digits and tank barge utilization in the high 80s to low 90% range. At the high-end, we are assuming year-over-year pricing stability going forward and utilization in the 90% to 95% range. We are assuming normal seasonal weather patterns for the remainder of the year. 
In the coastal market, on the high end of guidance, we are expecting flat to slightly higher pricing on contract renewals and utilization in the high 80% range. On the low end, our guidance range contemplates a deterioration in coastal rates, with pricing declines on contract renewals in the low single-digit percentage range and utilization in the mid-80% range. For our Diesel Engine Services segment, in our land-based sector, although oil prices have improved somewhat, it has not yet translated to an improved outlook. The improvement may come in the second half, but with lower spending levels seen in the first quarter, we felt it prudent to adjust this portion of our quarterly and full year guidance. We will continue to evaluate market conditions and adjust the cost structure as necessary to meet current and projected levels of demand. For the balance -- what must balance the lack of volume in today's market with the outlook for a market recovery, as oil prices continually increase. Where we fall within our guidance range of this year will partly hinge on whether we see an improvement in activity in the second half of the year. In our marine, diesel and power generation markets, we expect the weakness in the Gulf of Mexico oil service market to persist for the entire year. There is some possibility that major maintenance projects deferred by customers in the first quarter could drive better performance later this year. But our base case assumption is that those deferrals will not lead to firm orders until 2017. So in summary, our balance sheet and cash flow are in great shape, giving us the flexibility to do acquisitions and share repurchases. The Marine business is stable, with the inland markets poised for improvement and with a bright outlook for petrochemical volumes. Diesel Engine Services is weak, but with growing pent-up demand. In the diesel engine businesses, it is not a question of if the markets will come back, but a question of when. Operator, that concludes our prepared remarks. We're now ready to take questions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
