headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. With me today are Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski Vice President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial O
componenttext: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. With me today are Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski Vice President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website www.kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under the financial highlights. Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. I'll now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Thank you, Sterling. Yesterday afternoon we announced a second quarter earnings of $0.72 per share versus our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. That compares to a $1.04 per share reported for the 2015 second quarter. Inland Marine tan
componenttext:
Thank you. Thank you, Sterling. Yesterday afternoon we announced a second quarter earnings of $0.72 per share versus our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. That compares to a $1.04 per share reported for the 2015 second quarter. Inland Marine tank barge utilization during the second quarter was in the high 80% to low 90% range. Market continues to adjust in response to excess barge supply. That is influenced market over the past 12 to 18 months. Over a combination of retirements and volume will help bring the market back into balance, the transition has not been as smooth as we hoped it would be. 
As I'd mentioned -- as mentioned in our press release last night, in line utilization in July fell significantly and we have seen aggressive pricing from several carriers at levels -- at what we believe is at their full cost or in some cases, the cash cost. Such pricing in the market is historically unusual given the market fundamentals have not fundamentally changed that much since the start of the year and summer almost always sees a decline in utilization. Pricing at these levels, we believe is unsustainable, and if it persists, will lead to disruptive pressure on some last capitalize carriers. In the coastal market, tank barge utilization was in the mid 80% range. Utilization continues to be impacted by demand of equipment trading on the spot market, which adds vital time exposure. 
We continue to maintain a cautious outlook for this market as it absorbs the supply that is coming online through the first half of 2018. Remember that there is lot of over ship in the coastal market. In the land-based diesel engine service business, market conditions remain the best. Sales from the distribution of OEM engines, transmission and parts, which had been relatively stable in prior industry cycles are historically low levels. Additionally, orders for new pressure pumping units have not yet materialized. The remanufacturing and service side of the business is more positive and we have seen an increase in inquiries during the quarter as well as a number of firm orders. While limited activity does not lend itself to a materially better earnings outlook yet, hope it does represent the first in the market and the conditions will improve in the coming months. 
In the Marine and power generation Diesel Engine Services businesses, the oil field market along the Gulf Coast remains depressed while in the rest of the market service activities -- service activity is relatively stable. 
In summary, we continue to face an excess supply of equipment in Marine markets and a severe depression in the oilfield market. As we confront these challenges, we will continue to focus on safety, customer service, cost and capital discipline. In the inland market, we expect the market will be better later this year, and benefit from additional retirements of maintenance deferrals, consolidation as well as volumes from new chemical plants. For Kirby's parts, we will aggressively pursue our costs, aggressively service our customers and look for opportunities to prudently apply our balance sheet. I'll now turn the call over to David

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you Joe. Good morning to everyone on the call. I'll begin today with a summary of orderly results and each of our markets. Then I'll turn the call over to Andy to walk through the financials in more detail. After he finishes, I'll conclud
componenttext:
All right. Thank you Joe. Good morning to everyone on the call. I'll begin today with a summary of orderly results and each of our markets. Then I'll turn the call over to Andy to walk through the financials in more detail. After he finishes, I'll conclude with an explanation of our outlook and our guidance. In the inland Marine Transportation market, after a strong start to the second quarter in April, we experienced a modest decline in tank barge utilization into the high 80% range. The modest decline in utilization was largely attributable to our shorter in the spring season for products and soft demand in trading and refinery volumes, which we believe was largely related to high inventory levels. Pricing on churn contracts that were made during the second quarter was down in the mid-to high single digits on average. Spot rates were at or below term contract rates during the quarter. Operating conditions during the quarter were seasonally normal, although high cost currents floodgates and river crossings on the Gulf intercoastal waterway led to congestion and added delay at certain points along the Gulf Coast. In our Coastal Marine Transportation sector, demand for the transportation at Black oil and petrochemicals remain consistent with 2016 first quarter. While refined products demand was weaker, due primarily to lower demand in the Northeast. Relative to the first quarter, tank barge utilization declined slightly to the mid 80% range, a result of the continued trend of more equipment moving off of term contracts and trading in the spot market. As a reminder, most coastal barge term contracts are time charters, which had a 100% utilization and when equipment lose from time charter spot, even when it is highly utilized, the average utilization drops. 
With respect to pricing, term contracts that renewed during the second quarter increased to by a low single-digit percentage on average as several older contracts renewed in the quarter. However, term contracts that a year ago, and renewed during the quarter were at modestly lower rates. In our Diesel Engine Services segment, in our Marine, and Power Generation market, we continue to see deferrals of major overhaul projects. As has been the case, the Gulf of Mexico oilfield service market remained at depressed levels. In our land-based Diesel Engine Services market, the sale of engines, transmissions and parts in our distribution business remained at very depressed levels and have yet to show signs of improvement. Likewise, we have not had orders to manufacture a new pressure pumping units. On a more positive note, we did see incremental improvement in closing order activity for pressure pumping unit service in remanufacturing. The number of units serviced during the quarter was small, but we did have an uptick in labor and facility utilization, particularly late in the quarter and it continues into the early part of this quarter, the third quarter. It remains too early to call this activity a trend, but it does seem that we have at least seen the market in this cycle. I will now turn the call over to Andy to provide some detailed financial information, before I come back and discuss our outlook.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning. In the 2016 second quarter, Marine Transportation segment revenue declined 11% and operating income declined 25% as compared with the 2015 second quarter. A decline in revenue in the second quarter as compared to the prior
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning. In the 2016 second quarter, Marine Transportation segment revenue declined 11% and operating income declined 25% as compared with the 2015 second quarter. A decline in revenue in the second quarter as compared to the prior year quarter was primarily due to a 33% decline in the average cost of Marine diesel fuel, lower in Marine contract pricing and an increase in available spot market days for our offshore Marine equipment. The Marine Transportation segments operating margin was 19.2%, compared with 22.8% for the 2015 second quarter. The inland sector contributed approximately 2/3 of Marine Transportation revenue during the 2016 second quarter. Long-term inland Marine Transportation contracts does contracts with the term of one year or longer in duration, contributed approximately 80% of revenue with 51% of those contracts attributable to time charters and 49% from contracts. The inland sector generated in operating margin of low 20% rate for the quarter. In the coastal sector, the trend of customers electing to sort coastal equipment from the spot market over renewing existing contracts continued. However,, the percentage of cost of revenue under term contracts was consistent with the first quarter at approximately 78% probably as a result of lower utilization in revenue for sport equipment. The second quarter operating margin for the coastal sector was in the low double digits. 
Turning now to our Marine construction and retirement plans. During the 2016 first-half, we received 27 barges from the acquisition of Secor inland tank barge fleet, term delivery of 3 barges, transferred 130,000 barrels barge from coastal to inland service and retired a total of 28 barges. The net result was an increase of 3 tank barges to our inland tank barges fleet, which totaled approximately 345,000 barrels of capacity. For the second half of the year, we expect tank delivery of 430,000 barrels inland tank barges and to retire our charters an additional 11 barges with 135,000 barrels of capacity. 
On a net basis, we expect to end 2016 with approximately 18.2 million-barrel of capacity or roughly the same level we finished the second quarter, an increase of approximately 325,000 barrels from the end of 2015. In the coast wise transportation sector, our second new 185,000-barrel ATB began operating under a long-term customer contract in the June. The first of 2 new 155,000-barrel ATB should deliver in late 2016 and our second 155,000-barrel ATB on a coastal chemical barge are both expected to be completed in early 2017. 
Also during the second quarter this year, we retired a 80,000-barrel barge, and transport a 30,000-barrel coastal barge to our inland fleet ending the quarter with approximately 6.1 million barrels of capacity. In our press release last night, we also announced that we purchased 4 coastal tugboats during the second quarter for $26.5 million. The tugs will transition into service with existing barges in our fleet. The addition of this tugs will lower the age of our tug fleet, better align the age of our boats and barges and improve our operating performance. The average age of the boats we purchase is 8 years and the average age of the boats that are replacing is close to 40 years. 
Moving on to our Diesel Engine Services segment, revenue for the 2016 second quarter declined 46% from the 2015 second quarter and we had an operating loss in the segment of approximately $2 million. The segments operating margin was negative 3.1% compared with 4.2% for the 2015 second quarter. The Marine and power generation operations contributed approximately's 65% of the Diesel Engine Services revenue in the second quarter with an operating margin in the low double digits. Our land-based operations contributed roughly 35% of the Diesel Engine Services segments revenue in the second quarter with a double-digit negative operating margin. On the corporate side of our 2016 capital spending guidance remains in a range of $230 million to $250 million, including approximately $10 million from construction of 7 inland tank barges to be delivered in 2016, approximately $100 million in progress payments on new coastal equipments including one,185,000-barrel coastal ATB, 2 155,000-barrel coastal ATB's, 2 4900-horsepower coastal tugboats and a new coastal petrochemical tank barge. The balance of $120 million to $140 million is primarily for capital upgrades and improvements to existing inland and coastal Marine equipment and facilities as well as Diesel Engine Services facilities. In addition to our capital spending guidance, we spent $81 million on the acquisition of the Secor inland tank barge fleet with an additional $4 million paid in July for a tugboat, which was under construction. We also spent $13.5 million to acquire our least coastal bars from a lessor and $26.5 million to purchase 4 coastal tugboats. Total debt as of June 30th, 2016 was $799 million, a $24-million increase from December 31, 2015. Our debt to capital ratio at June 30, 2016 was 25.4%, unchanged from December 31, 2015. As of today, our debt stands at $786 million. I'll now turn the call back over to David

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 third quarter guidance of $0.50 to $0.65 per share. And we lowered our full year 2016 guidance to a range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Let me take a moment and provide a general overview of our app
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 third quarter guidance of $0.50 to $0.65 per share. And we lowered our full year 2016 guidance to a range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Let me take a moment and provide a general overview of our approach to guidance this quarter. In the second quarter, we saw a strong utilization informing pricing in the inland market in April with the rest of the quarter lying out on our expectations as you saw with our second quarter result, which fell within our guidance range. However, in July, we've seen our inland utilization fall into the low 80% range. Given the lower inland Marine utilization, we are seeing a very competitive pricing environment. We are lowering guidance to reflect these conditions. And on the low end of our range, we are factoring in a continuation of this environment through the remainder of the year. 
In terms of inland marine utilization, tank barge utilization does typically falls slightly in the summer when good operating conditions reduce congestion and improve efficiency throughout the waterways. However, so far this quarter, utilization has remained in the low 80% range, lower than we would expect. We do think that weaker utilization levels are partly related factors that are temporary in nature including high refinery and turmoil inventory levels and reduced trading activity in the black oil markets. As it remains unclear how long these utilization levels will persist, we have lowered our guidance. In terms of pricing, we expect spot and contract renewal pricing to continue to be under pressure during the quarter. As Joe mentioned, we believe spot pricing and inland market has reached unsustainable levels and that sport rates now reflect pricing that is below cash be breakeven's for some carriers. If this pricing versus, we believe potential sellers will materialize either through choice or distress. We will deploy our capital appropriately should that occur. In the coastal market, on the low-end, our guidance range contemplates pricing declines on contract renewals in the low single-digit percent range and utilization in the low to mid 80% range. On the high-end of guidance, we're expecting flat pricing on contract renewals and utilization in the high 80% range. For our Diesel Engine Services and our land-based sector, we expect to incur quarterly operating losses of a similar magnitude as in the first half of the year. However, our results may improve at service activities, which picked up in late June continue to improve. In our diesel markets, we do -- diesel -- marine diesel markets, we do not expect an improvement in the Gulf of Mexico oil service market this year. In the power generation market and then our other marine diesel engine services market, we expect results to be lastly consistent with the 2016 second quarter. 
In closing, our financial position is strong. We have a strong balance sheet, a young, well-maintained fleet and healthy free cash flow. As both our Marine Transportation and Diesel Engine Services markets undergo difficult times, we will focus on safe operation, customer service and cost containment by looking to deploy cash flow where we can find high return projects in a discipline and accretive manner. As we look beyond this year, we are much more constructive on the outlook across our markets. In the past few days, many large oilfield operators have stated their belief that the worst of the energy market collapse is behind us. We believe that is the case as well. For the second half of next year, if not earlier, we expect to see volumes increase in our land-based diesel engine business. Similarly, in our Marine Transportation markets, the worst of the correction, which arose from overbuilding into the crude markets is likely behind us. While the aggressive pricing in the market this quarter is troubling, it likely yields opportunities that would not otherwise be there or at a minimum should force capacity discipline on some operators who have not shown much discipline lately. 
A rationalization of supply this year provides a better environment for growth next year, particularly in the chemical markets where we expect growth to accelerate through next year. 
Operator, that concludes our prepared remarks. And we are now ready to take questions.

But then also that -- the current rates, in many cases are below cash breakeven and nonsustainable. I don't want to, but that is kind of worst-case scenario, that is more likely to play out in a shorter period of time than the longer period of time?

componenttext: Yes, that is worst-case scenario. And that, what I said was related to low-end of our guidance. We actually do think that some of this disruption we think, particularly as it relates to high product inventories across the system now. We think that's pretty temporary in nature and we should get utilization back as the year progress. But in the low-end of our guidance, we wanted to kind of say, okay, what if it doesn't come back, and that's how we got to below end.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any way to quantify what part of the percentage drop in July is tied to inventories alone, and I guess, therefore, the inability to move progress?
componenttext: Is there any way to quantify what part of the percentage drop in July is tied to inventories alone, and I guess, therefore, the inability to move progress?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's difficult to quantify because there are other things that, as we mentioned, just a better summer weather, we usually get some increase efficiencies, which props utilization. But we've also, in the black oil markets, it's feedstock prices have moved a
componenttext: It's difficult to quantify because there are other things that, as we mentioned, just a better summer weather, we usually get some increase efficiencies, which props utilization. But we've also, in the black oil markets, it's feedstock prices have moved around and we've seen some times the arbitrage closes and sometimes it opens back up, so the black oil fleet utilization moves around a bit with that. So it's not just inventory levels, then also you got the strong dollar what can affect imports and exports for that matter. And that can move things around there. So it's short answer, it's hard to quantify it and how much of its related to inventories. But I would say a good portion of it. I couldn't put a percentage on it, but it is a decent percentage of.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And just kind of a bigger picture question, can you help us think about the margin outlook in both the inland and coastal business, should these current condition persist in the back half of the year? And then specifically, I'm trying to get my head around the operating margin impact of more customers opting for spot versus contracted news on the coastal side.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly pricing has an impact on margins and you would think that they will go down. And that's part of what's in our guidance for the third and fourth quarter. Now, as utilization starts to come back, we do get a pick up from that. So we think util
componenttext: Well, clearly pricing has an impact on margins and you would think that they will go down. And that's part of what's in our guidance for the third and fourth quarter. Now, as utilization starts to come back, we do get a pick up from that. So we think utilization will come back and most of this is temporary. So it's a balance, but clearly we've -- and if you look at the margin impact is in our guidance. Now in terms of spot versus contract, the move to more spot actually gives you -- give you some leverage when things start coming back because you're not locked into lower pricing. A lot of what you're seeing in this pricing environment has just been in the spot market, so very few contracts are being signed up at these low levels.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext:
It could potentially, yes, we are in lower double digits now and clearly as the spot -- the most spot you have on the coastal side, you just don't get the continuous void. So yes, you don't shed the cost, but you don't have as much revenue. So you're correct, it could go into the high single digits.
Kelly, just to clarify on my free cash flow number, I want to make sure you understood that, that does not include the acquisition spend. That's over that.

componenttext: So I guess, David, just kind of think about the pricing dynamics on the inland side, looking for, you talked about unsustainably low spot pricing what sort of at or below the breakeven price for some players in the market. Could you give us a sense for really where spot rates and contractual rates are today, relative to both the prior peak in '14 and then the trough during the recession in '09. So where are we in that continual with both of those type of rates?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are -- I'm saying from the peak in '14, we're probably down 20, maybe even 25%. And then from the last downturn, say '09, spot prices are little below that. Part of that is, frankly, we've got some undisciplined players in the market that impacted it b
componenttext: We are -- I'm saying from the peak in '14, we're probably down 20, maybe even 25%. And then from the last downturn, say '09, spot prices are little below that. Part of that is, frankly, we've got some undisciplined players in the market that impacted it below what on the last cycle. But, yes, that's why we think we're close to the bottom here because it's hard to envision a very longer -- a longer-term pricing environment where you're at or below cost -- cash cost, it's not sustainable.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then that's helpful. And shifting gears over to diesel engine side, I know a lot of work has been done there to remove excess operating expenses there, just given the cycle we've seen in the oilfield services market. But as you think about that
componenttext: Okay. And then that's helpful. And shifting gears over to diesel engine side, I know a lot of work has been done there to remove excess operating expenses there, just given the cycle we've seen in the oilfield services market. But as you think about that business potentially recovering in '17 or perhaps second half of '17, I'm curious what you think the land-based margin in the Diesel Engine Services segment could like over the course of the next cycle. I know typically it's been high single digits. With all the cost actions and rationalization in that business for you guys, what is the -- how should we think about that business looking for a profitability perspective coming out of this?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Hey, Jack, this is Andy. With some of the cost initiatives that we've taken on and some of the improvements that we've made in our process in our business, we think that we can probably easily add an additional 300 to 400 basis points of margin to that business over the next cycle.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question will come from Gregory Lewis of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my first question would be around on the inland and the coastal side. Joe mentioned that you guys retired an 80,000 barrels coastal barge earlier this year. As we look at both those markets, sort of over the next 12 months, in terms of -- what vi
componenttext: I guess, my first question would be around on the inland and the coastal side. Joe mentioned that you guys retired an 80,000 barrels coastal barge earlier this year. As we look at both those markets, sort of over the next 12 months, in terms of -- what visibility have, exclusive of retirements, what type of fleet growth do expect to see in Inland and do you expect to see in coastal?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think let me take Inland first. Clearly, we are in an oversupplied market right now. will go to must equipment. And in this kind of market, with this kind of prices, as maintenance decisions come up, certainly nobody would want to built into
componenttext: Yes, well, I think let me take Inland first. Clearly, we are in an oversupplied market right now. will go to must equipment. And in this kind of market, with this kind of prices, as maintenance decisions come up, certainly nobody would want to built into this market right now. No rational player would want to add capacity in this environment, and I think, as you look at maintenance decisions that come up on say a 25-year-old or 30-year-old barge, you probably tie it up at best and maybe you just retire it and cut it up and sell for scrap because at this market, those kind of decisions become easier and this is why we see in these kind of environments, the number of retirements go up and the building go down. As we look at the 2017 order book, we are not hearing much at all being led in terms of contract. So in terms of the inland fleet growth, I don't think there will be much if any, at all, and with retirements, it should contract. On the coastwise side, it's a little more balanced in that you got some new capacity coming in including some of ours over the next to 18 months. I think in total, it's -- the ones that haven't delivered, maybe it's 14 units. And there are still over 40 units that are 30 years or older in the coastwise business. And they need to come out. The netting requirements from our customers are getting tougher and then the offshore environment, they are even tougher than the inland side, and age is a factor there. So I think you'll see more retirement on the coastwise side. The question is the balance between the new additions in the retirements and how that plays out. But I don't think you'll see overall capacity growth, volume growth on the coastwise side in the barges, there are 200,000 and less.

Is that enough to sort of move coastal margins a couple basic points or it that more just not -- like not really going to have much of an impact?

componenttext: It's probably positive. But I'm not sure it's going to move the needle. If you think about it, and let me clarify, but -- 4 tugs not barges, if we are retiring a 40-year old barge barges.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, right.
componenttext: Sure, right.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Replacing them with much younger. So what happens is you get a little more depreciation, but the offset of that is, you get higher reliability, lower maintenance cost and just better utilization out of them. Because there is fewer maintenance days, fewer
componenttext: Replacing them with much younger. So what happens is you get a little more depreciation, but the offset of that is, you get higher reliability, lower maintenance cost and just better utilization out of them. Because there is fewer maintenance days, fewer down days and clearly the younger fleet is more attractive for return customers as well. Now, to quantify that in terms of margin, I don't think I can quantify that and I'm not sure it would be that much -- that material. But it certainly is a positive.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question will come from Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dave, when you guys talked about the pricing before in terms of the great recession, how about utilization. You talked about it dropping to the low mid 80s, where did you see utilization getting to -- how low can this go. And then, I guess the utilizat
componenttext: So Dave, when you guys talked about the pricing before in terms of the great recession, how about utilization. You talked about it dropping to the low mid 80s, where did you see utilization getting to -- how low can this go. And then, I guess the utilization concept, you talked much about the remaining crude barges. Is there anything left on that side to still come in -- is that's what creating some of this excess sexes capacity. Are they now all in petrochemical. And I guess, sticking with that, a lot of discussion on pricing, but I think on the demand side, anything happened with the new plants. Is there something that's coming on mind you look out and you it turn that can drive this?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, let me to take those, try and do them in order. In '09, there was a quarter we dipped into the high '70s. But I think it was just 1 quarter. So it's not as bad as that, low 80s is pretty difficult environment in terms of utilization. In terms o
componenttext:
Yes, sure, let me to take those, try and do them in order. In '09, there was a quarter we dipped into the high '70s. But I think it was just 1 quarter. So it's not as bad as that, low 80s is pretty difficult environment in terms of utilization. In terms of crude barges, I think last quarter we said we estimated there about 175 or so barges still moving crude. And that was down from 550. Our latest poll indicates it's probably around a 140 barges. So sure, that did have some impact, it went from 175 down to 140. It's interesting, you'll see, you read some of the snippets that deeper in the Utica, come and start drilling again. So who knows if we've hit on the could barges, but clearly the barges that have come out of crude have been cleaned up and put into clean service by and large, which has impacted utilization for sure. Now, to your broader question about demand, if you look across all of our product -- products that we carry, outside of crude, everything is pretty good. Crude's down for sure. But if you look at the chemicals, they are okay. And we do see continued building. I think one of our customers just announced a new joint venture that they're going to build a new facility on the Gulf Coast. There has been 1 or 2 delays, but by and large, most of the chemical facilities that have been announced and they have started construction are still going on. So that's a positive. 
Refined products outside of this product that were in are now that's impacting kind of some movements. If you look at vehicle miles driven, they are up in refine products demand, it's still going, I think the production has outpaced it recently. And that's caused this kind of disruption or product if you will. And then you look at some of the other products. Outside of crude, everything is okay and fairly healthy. It's just we've got a little dislocation now where things have to come back into balance.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, I appreciate if I could get a follow-up on the -- your comment on the particular players that are more aggressive. I just want to understand, in that phase, when you're going through this, you take up the pay contracts, which kind of are your basis
componenttext: Great, I appreciate if I could get a follow-up on the -- your comment on the particular players that are more aggressive. I just want to understand, in that phase, when you're going through this, you take up the pay contracts, which kind of are your basis, for I guess, stability or kind of some stability that. What happens to those contracts as they come up for renewal. Do they tend to be higher than average contract pricing and so that's why you see, maybe a little bit more volatility or is it just anything that's get touched, it's just coming down to the current spot levels?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what you're seeing because there is equipment availability, some of the term contracts. And this is across the industry, not Kirby specific. There are some term contracts aren't getting renewed and they are just going to the spot market for a while.
componenttext: Yes, what you're seeing because there is equipment availability, some of the term contracts. And this is across the industry, not Kirby specific. There are some term contracts aren't getting renewed and they are just going to the spot market for a while. Now that's not, I don't want to overstate that, that's not a huge number. But there are a number of term contracts that are going to the spot market because the availability is there. And that the operators think the shippers aren't as concerned about the availability. Now as things start typing up that will reverse itself. And we would expect that to start happen again later this year.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Michael Webber of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Michael Webber of Wells Fargo.

componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to some of the pricing pressure conversation you were having a bit earlier, and maybe kind of backing away from kind of a natural inclination, the markets used to have to find a slower surprising or kind of setting a bottom. But if

Is that something that's typically measured in quarters or in years when you guys go back and look at past 2 or 3 or 4 cycles you've been a part of.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think firstly, you need to separate what drove the some of the cycles in the past, and what's driving this one. Cycles in the past have been -- been principally driven by recessions and where volumes have declined and you really needed to have a kind of
componenttext: I think firstly, you need to separate what drove the some of the cycles in the past, and what's driving this one. Cycles in the past have been -- been principally driven by recessions and where volumes have declined and you really needed to have a kind of a cleansing of the industry. You needed one of the economy to recover volumes to improve and some equipment to come out. This particular downturn is not economically driven. It's -- it really is affected by a couple of things. It's affected by building barges for a market, the crude oil market that then collapsed as crude oil collapsed. And it's affected by what I think is a -- an anomaly, which is high inventories and the market adjusting to those inventory. We saw something similar to that in 2008, in the beginning of 2009, where you did have an economic collapse, but you also had an anonymous adjustment in inventories. And that was relatively short. There are some other things that are going on, I think, during this particular period. You have the summer weather affect that David talked about. And that's something that we really haven't seen in last 3 or 4 years because the market's been so tight, hasn't been an of equipment. But if you go back to the last 30 years before that, you always had utilization drill down the summer as the system got more efficient and there was more equipment on the market to come fall, tighten up again. So I think what's happened here is that you have some operators that are already worried about crude oil equipment that builds -- that don't have -- doesn't have home for it. As any of had this summer doldrums that have been traditionally seen in the business. they panicked and they lowered prices just to both equipment, which has drugged the whole market down. As you get some adjustments of inventory, as you go into the fall where system isn't as efficient, it gets a little less efficient, you'll see utilization get better and I think pricing will follow it. How long it takes to absorb the crude oil overhand, will really be a driven by 2 things. One, equipment going out of the market and some of that is happening now. You're already getting maintenance referrals. So you're going to see less available equipment going forward in the year. And then the volumes that David talked about. You got strong refined products, markets, record miles driven in the U.S. and I think people are predicting that that's going to continue given that the low gasoline prices. And then you have this volumes that are coming from the chemical business. So it's going to correct itself. I think you'll begin to see at the end of -- towards the end of the year, and 2017, barring any economic issue, you should see continued correction, higher utilization and more normalcy in pricing.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Fair enough. And just to follow-up on that, Joe. You mentioned kind of pet chem cycle, potentially starting some point in kind of 17, '18, though when you think about the kind of the enhanced focus around gasoline and kind of get away from and some of the quarters, when you think about barge and market share, kind of overall pet chem production kind of relative to real in the pipeline. And you think about what that mix looks like going forward and yields look like going forward from the pet chem space. Do you think that barge market share technically grows or just given what we're likely to be.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should grow. Pipelines aren't conducive to types of chemicals that we carry. Barging is much more flexible, because you can sort said from different plants, you can move it into different markets. The pipeline is -- you put it in the pipeline, it comes
componenttext: It should grow. Pipelines aren't conducive to types of chemicals that we carry. Barging is much more flexible, because you can sort said from different plants, you can move it into different markets. The pipeline is -- you put it in the pipeline, it comes out where the pipeline ends. And it also requires steady volumes of some significant nature. That's really not the chemical business. Barging is -- has been the really the principal way of moving chemicals around, because of the flexibility and because of the volumes it typically see. Railroads are competitive depending on where you are moving the chemicals and how much your moving. You remember that -- the smallest barge that we operate is equal to, I think, 16 road parts. So if you got more -- you got less in the barge load than rail makes a lot of sense. If you are taking it to a place that barging doesn't rail makes a lot of sense. But typically, most moments, rail is a not a competitive factor. So I would think that we're going to add more than our share.

componenttext: You have to almost go back to the 80s where you saw this kind of predatory pricing. In 2001 through 2003, we saw some low prices, but I don't recall of being at cash prices. And we -- I think, David, we have to clarify that not all, not every deal is done this way. It just, you have several operators that I think have gotten way more nervous than they should be. Based on some decisions they made with respect to building equipment and then this inventory problem coupled with seasonality that we talked about that are just panic, I can't imagine that -- that they're going to carry this forward. Once I see the market improve a little bit, which it really should do just driven by the fact that we're going to be left efficient going into the fall and the winter.

componenttext: I don't think it meets the chemical cycle. If anything, I think where it ends up happening is we get some capacity rationalization out of this. And certainly, it should dampen any enthusiasm to build. And I think that's a positive. I think it, for some operators that are more highly levered, it really puts them in a tough way, which makes them less likely to go, produce something like build new capacity. So if anything, I don't think this down cycle mutes the benefit from pet chem and if anything, it helps because it is so stinging right now, bring some discipline into the market.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add one more thing, John, I think this is worthy to note. We're down on crude oil. Because crude oil prices are such that they are some significant restraints to it. drilling for crude oil in the U.S. And we tend to think that, that's going to
componenttext: Let me just add one more thing, John, I think this is worthy to note. We're down on crude oil. Because crude oil prices are such that they are some significant restraints to it. drilling for crude oil in the U.S. And we tend to think that, that's going to go on forever and it's not. I mean, the world's demand for crude oil in the U.S. position, barring some regulations, I don't think we're going to see, is very important to the world oil supply. And we have said this in the past and I think it's worth saying it again, is that barging is going to be, one of the ways you're going to move crude oil from the market. And when the lions come back, you're going to move more volumes of crude oil. And that's also going to have a stabilizing effect on the fleet. Think that the Halliburton said the other day in the earnings call that those 2021, the world needed close to $18 million more barrels of oil. That's an enormous amount of oil. And some of that is going to have to come from the U.S. shale effort. And we're going to get some of those lions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's interesting, John. I think -- because it's been so painful in the pressure pumping business, I think capital there is not as plentiful an what you're seeing and what we're seeing from our customer base is a lot more reman in service, almost no
componenttext: Well, it's interesting, John. I think -- because it's been so painful in the pressure pumping business, I think capital there is not as plentiful an what you're seeing and what we're seeing from our customer base is a lot more reman in service, almost no discussion about any new capacity. So it's kind of like the reason we said we've get into this business. We thought there would be a lot of reman business, just because capital discipline would work. And I think we're starting to see that play out where we getting a lot of inquiries about the pairing equipment and remanufacturing equipment. Now, there is some interesting things going on. We heard some of the oil service commentary that you don't need 1800 rigs to absorb the pressure pumping fleet. I think it's closer to 900. So that service intensity plus the attrition in fleet, so I think on the pressure pumping side, you're going to see that market tighten up pretty quickly. And they need it. I mean our pressure pumping customers have been cash constrained. So I don't think there is a long way of saying we are not seeing new equipment orders. I don't think, they will reemerge, but right now, the demand for is growing, and to us, it's very encouraging.

Good morning, and welcome to the Kirby Corporation 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Sterling Adlakha. Please go ahead.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me today are Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski, Kirby's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Fina
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me today are Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chairman; David Grzebinski, Kirby's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Smith, Kirby's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at www.kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under the financial highlights. 
Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
I'll now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Thank you, Sterling. Yesterday afternoon, we announced second quarter earnings of $0.72 per share versus our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. That compares to a $1.04 per share reported for the 2015 second quarter. Inland marine tank
componenttext:
Thank you. Thank you, Sterling. Yesterday afternoon, we announced second quarter earnings of $0.72 per share versus our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. That compares to a $1.04 per share reported for the 2015 second quarter. Inland marine tank barge utilization during the second quarter was in the high 80% to low 90% range. Market continues to adjust in response to excess barge supply. That has influenced market over the past 12 to 18 months. Although a combination of retirements and volume will help bring the market back into balance, the transition has not been as smooth as we hoped it would be. 
As I've -- as mentioned in our press release last night, inland utilization in July fell significantly, and we have seen aggressive pricing from several carriers at levels -- at what we believe is at their full cost or, in some cases, their cash costs. Such pricing in the market is historically unusual, given the market fundamentals have not fundamentally changed that much since the start of the year and summer almost always sees a decline in utilization. Pricing at these levels, we believe, is unsubstainable, and if it persists, will lead to destructive pressure on some less well-capitalized carriers. 
In the coastal market, tank barge utilization was in the mid-80% range. Utilization continues to be impacted by the amount of equipment trading on the spot market, which adds vital time exposure. We continue to maintain a cautious outlook for this market as it absorbs new supply that is coming online through the first half of 2018. Remember that there is a lot of older tonnage ship in the coastal market. 
In the land-based diesel engine service business, market conditions remained depressed. Sales from the distribution of OEM engines, transmissions and parts, which have been relatively stable in prior industry cycles, are historically low levels. Additionally, orders for new pressure pumping units have not yet materialized. 
The remanufacturing and service side of the business is more positive, and we have seen an increase in inquiries during the quarter as well as a number of firm orders. While such limited activity does not lend itself to a materially better earnings outlook yet, our hope it does represent the first green shoots in the market and the conditions will improve in the coming months. 
In the marine and power generation diesel engine service businesses, the oilfield market along the Gulf Coast remains depressed, while in the rest of our market, service activities -- service activity is relatively stable. 
In summary, we continue to face an excess supply of equipment in the marine markets and a severe cyclical depression in the oilfield market. As we confront these challenges, we will continue to focus on safety, customer service, cost and capital discipline. In the inland market, we expect the market will get better later this year and benefit from additional retirements of maintenance deferrals, consolidation as well as volumes from new chemical plants. For Kirby's part, we will aggressively pursue our costs, aggressively service our customers and look for opportunities to prudently apply our balance sheet. 
I'll now turn the call over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Joe. Good morning to everyone on the call. I'll begin today with a summary of quarterly results in each of our markets, then I'll turn the call over to Andy to walk through the financials in more detail. After he finishes, I'll concl
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Joe. Good morning to everyone on the call. I'll begin today with a summary of quarterly results in each of our markets, then I'll turn the call over to Andy to walk through the financials in more detail. After he finishes, I'll conclude with an explanation of our outlook and our guidance. 
In the inland marine transportation market, after a strong start to the second quarter in April, we experienced a modest decline in tank barge utilization into the high 80% range. The modest decline in utilization was largely attributable to a shortened spring season for ag products and soft demand in trading and refinery volumes, which we believe was largely related to high inventory levels. 
Pricing on term contracts that renewed during the second quarter was down in the mid- to high single digits on average. Spot rates were at/or below term contract rates during the quarter. Operating conditions during the quarter were seasonally normal, although high cross currents at floodgates and river crossings on the Gulf Intercoastal Waterway led to congestion and added delays at certain points along the Gulf Coast. 
In our coastal marine transportation sector, demand for the coastwise transportation of black oil and petrochemicals remained consistent with the 2016 first quarter, while refined products demand was weaker, due primarily to lower demand in the Northeast. Relative to the first quarter, tank barge utilization declined slightly to the mid-80% range, a result of the continued trend of more equipment moving off of term contracts and trading in the spot market. As a reminder, most coastal barge term contracts are time charters, which have a 100% utilization. And when equipment lose from time-chartered spot, even when it is highly utilized, the average utilization drops. 
With respect to pricing, term contracts that renewed during the second quarter increased by a low single-digit percentage on average as several older contracts renewed in the quarter. However, term contracts that were signed a year ago and renewed during the quarter were at modestly lower rates. 
In our diesel engine services segment in our marine diesel and power generation markets, we continue to see deferrals of major overhaul projects. As has been the case, the Gulf of Mexico oilfield service market remained at depressed levels. 
In our land-based diesel engine services market, the sale of engines, transmissions and parts in our distribution business remained at very depressed levels and have yet to show signs of improvement. Likewise, we have not had orders to manufacture new pressure pumping units. 
On a more positive note, we did see incremental improvement in quote and order activity for pressure pumping unit service in remanufacturing. The number of units serviced during the quarter was small, but we did have an uptick in labor and facility utilization, particularly late in the quarter and it continues into the early part of this quarter, the third quarter. 
It remains too early to call this activity a trend, but it does seem that we have at least seen the worst of the market in this cycle. 
I'll now turn the call over to Andy to provide some detailed financial information before I come back and discuss our outlook.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning. In the 2016 second quarter, marine transportation segment revenue declined 11% and operating income declined 25% as compared with the 2015 second quarter. The decline in revenue in the second quarter as compared to the pri
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning. In the 2016 second quarter, marine transportation segment revenue declined 11% and operating income declined 25% as compared with the 2015 second quarter. The decline in revenue in the second quarter as compared to the prior year quarter was primarily due to a 33% decline in the average cost of marine diesel fuel, lower inland marine contract pricing and an increase in available spot market days for our offshore marine equipment. The marine transportation segment's operating margin was 19.2% compared with 22.8% for the 2015 second quarter. 
The inland sector contributed approximately 2/3 of marine transportation revenue during the 2016 second quarter. Long-term inland marine transportation contracts, those contracts with the term of 1 year or longer in duration, contributed approximately 80% of revenue, with 51% of those contracts attributable to time charters and 49% affreightment contracts. 
The inland sector generated an operating margin in the low 20% range for the quarter. In the coastal sector, the trend of customers electing to source coastal equipment from the spot market over renewing existing contracts continued. However, the percentage of coastal revenue under term contracts was consistent with the first quarter at approximately 78%, probably as a result of lower utilization in revenue for spot equipment. The second quarter operating margin for the coastal sector was in the low double digits. 
Turning now to our marine construction and retirement plans. During the 2016 first half, we received 27 barges from the acquisition of Seacor's inland tank barge fleet, took delivery of 3 barges, transferred 1 30,000-barrel barge from coastal to inland service, and retired a total of 28 barges. The net result was an increase of 3 tank barges to our inland tank barge fleet, which totaled approximately 345,000 barrels of capacity. For the second half of the year, we expect to take delivery of 4 30,000-barrel inland tank barges and to retire or return to charters an additional 11 barges with 135,000 barrels of capacity. 
On a net basis, we expect to end 2016 with approximately 18.2 million barrels of capacity or roughly the same level we finished in second quarter, an increase of approximately 325,000 barrels from the end of 2015. 
In the coastwise transportation sector, our second new 185,000-barrel ATB began operating under a long-term customer contract in mid-June. The first of 2 new 155,000-barrel ATB should deliver in late 2016 and our second 155,000-barrel ATB on a coastal chemical barge are both expected to be completed in early 2017. 
Also, during the second quarter of this year, we retired an 80,000-barrel barge and transport a 30,000-barrel coastal barge to our inland fleet, ending the quarter with approximately 6.1 million barrels of capacity. 
In our press release last night, we also announced that we purchased 4 coastal tugboats during the second quarter for $26.5 million. The tugs will transition into service with existing barges in our fleet. The addition of these tugs will lower the age of our tug fleet, better align the age of our boats and barges, and improve our operating performance. The average age of the boats we purchased is 8 years and the average age of the boats they're replacing is close to 40 years. 
Moving on to our diesel engine services segment. Revenue for the 2016 second quarter declined 46% from the 2015 second quarter and we had an operating loss in the segment of approximately $2 million. The segment's operating margin was negative 3.1% compared with 4.2% for the 2015 second quarter. The marine and power generation operations contributed approximately 65% of the diesel engine services revenue in the second quarter, with an operating margin in the low double digits. Our land-based operations contributed roughly 35% of the diesel engine services segment's revenue in the second quarter, with a double-digit negative operating margin. 
On the corporate side of things. Our 2016 capital spending guidance remains in a range of $230 million to $250 million, including approximately $10 million from construction of 7 inland tank barges to be delivered in 2016; approximately $100 million in progress payments on new coastal equipment, including 1 185,000-barrel coastal ATB, 2 155,000-barrel coastal ATBs, 2 4,900-horsepower coastal tugboats and a new coastal petrochemical tank barge. The balance of $120 million to $140 million is primarily for capital upgrades and improvements to existing inland and coastal marine equipment and facilities as well as diesel engine services facilities. 
In addition to our capital spending guidance, we spent $81 million on the acquisition of the Seacor inland tank barge fleet, with an additional $45 million [ph] paid in July for a tugboat which was under construction. We also spent $13.5 million to acquire or lease coastal barge from a lessor and $26.5 million to purchase 4 coastal tugboats. 
Total debt as of June 30, 2016, was $799 million, a $24 million increase from December 31, 2015. Our debt to cap ratio at June 30, 2016, was 25.4%, unchanged from December 31, 2015. As of today, our debt stands at $786 million. 
I'll now turn the call back over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 third quarter guidance of $0.50 to $0.65 per share and we lowered our full year 2016 guidance to a range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Let me take a moment and provide a general overview of our appr
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy. In our press release, we announced our 2016 third quarter guidance of $0.50 to $0.65 per share and we lowered our full year 2016 guidance to a range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Let me take a moment and provide a general overview of our approach to guidance this quarter. 
In the second quarter, we saw a strong utilization and firming pricing in the inland market in April, with the rest of the quarter playing out around our expectations, as you saw with our second quarter result, which fell within our guidance range. However, in July, we've seen our inland utilization fall into the low 80% range. Given the lower inland marine utilization, we are seeing a very competitive pricing environment. We are lowering guidance to reflect these conditions. And on the low end of the range, we are factoring in a continuation of this environment through the remainder of the year. 
In terms of inland marine utilization, tank barge utilization does typically fall slightly in the summer when good operating conditions reduce congestion and improve efficiency throughout the waterways. However, so far this quarter, utilization has remained in the low 80% range, lower than we would expect. We do think that weaker utilization levels are partly related to factors that are temporary in nature, including high refinery and thermal [ph] inventory levels and reduced trading activity in the black oil markets. 
As it remains unclear how long these utilization levels will persist, we have lowered our guidance. In terms of pricing, we expect spot and contract renewal pricing to continue to be under pressure during the quarter. As Joe mentioned, we believe spot pricing in the inland market has reached unsustainable levels and that spot rates now reflect pricing that is below cash breakevens for some carriers. If this pricing persists, we believe potential sellers will materialize either through choice or distress. We will deploy our capital appropriately should that occur. 
In the coastal market, on the low end, our guidance range contemplates pricing declines on contract renewals in the low single-digit percent range and utilization in the low to mid-80% range. On the high end of guidance, we are expecting flat pricing on contract renewals and utilization in the high 80% range. For our diesel engine service segment in our land-based sector, we expect to incur quarterly operating losses of a similar magnitude as in the first half of the year. However, our results may improve if service activities, which picked up in late June, continue to improve. 
In our diesel markets, we do -- diesel -- marine diesel markets, we do not expect any improvement in the Gulf of Mexico oil service market this year. In the power generation market and on our other marine diesel engine services market, we expect results to be largely consistent with the 2016 second quarter. 
In closing, our financial position is strong. We have a strong balance sheet, a young, well-maintained fleet and healthy free cash flow. As both our marine transportation and diesel engine services markets undergo difficult times, we will focus on safe operation, customer service and cost containment while looking to deploy cash flow where we can find high return projects in a disciplined and accretive manner. As we look beyond this year, we are much more constructive on the outlook across our markets. 
In the past few days, many large oilfield operators have stated their belief that the worst of the energy market collapse is behind us. We believe that is the case as well. By the second half of next year, if not earlier, we expect to see volumes increase in our land-based diesel engine business. 
Similarly, in our marine transportation markets, the worst of the correction which arose from overbuilding into the crude markets, is likely behind us. While the aggressive pricing in the market this quarter is troubling, it likely yields opportunities that would not otherwise be there or at a minimum should force capacity discipline on some operators who have not shown much discipline lately. 
A rationalization of supply this year provides a better environment for growth next year, particularly in the chemical markets where we expect growth to accelerate through next year. 
Operator, that concludes our prepared remarks. And we're now ready to take questions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Jon Chappell of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Jon Chappell of Evercore ISI.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, if I just put some of your last comments together and try to figure out the duration of maybe this pricing pressure, you said in the guidance that you're expecting spot to remain under pressure for the remainder of this year. But then also that the
componenttext: David, if I just put some of your last comments together and try to figure out the duration of maybe this pricing pressure, you said in the guidance that you're expecting spot to remain under pressure for the remainder of this year. But then also that the current rates, in many cases, are below cash breakeven and nonsustainable. I don't want to put words in your mouth, but is that kind of like a worst-case scenario that's more likely to play out in a shorter period of time than the longer period of time?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Now that is the worst-case scenario. And that -- what I said was that was related to our low end of guidance. We actually do think that some of this disruption we see, particularly as it relates to high product inventories across the system now,
componenttext: Yes, yes. Now that is the worst-case scenario. And that -- what I said was that was related to our low end of guidance. We actually do think that some of this disruption we see, particularly as it relates to high product inventories across the system now, we think that's pretty temporary in nature and we should get utilization back as the year progress. But in the low end of our guidance, we wanted to kind of just say, "Okay, what if it doesn't come back?" And that's how we got to below end.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any way to quantify what part of the percentage drop in July is tied to inventories alone, and I guess, therefore, the inability to move cargoes?
componenttext: Is there any way to quantify what part of the percentage drop in July is tied to inventories alone, and I guess, therefore, the inability to move cargoes?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's difficult to quantify because there are other things, as we mentioned, just a better summer weather. We usually get some increased efficiencies, which drops utilization. But we've also -- in the black oil markets, if feedstock prices have moved aroun
componenttext: It's difficult to quantify because there are other things, as we mentioned, just a better summer weather. We usually get some increased efficiencies, which drops utilization. But we've also -- in the black oil markets, if feedstock prices have moved around and we've seen -- sometimes the arbitrage closes and sometimes it opens back up, and so the black oil fleet utilization moves around a bit with that. So it's not just inventory levels, then also you've got the strong dollar what can affect imports and exports for that matter. And that can move things around there. So it's -- short answer, it's hard to quantify it and how much of it is related to inventories. But I would say, a good portion of it. Yes, I couldn't put a percentage on it, but it is a decent percentage of it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just for clarification -- I'm sorry, one last [indiscernible] When we think about the term versus the spot, when would you say that the term pressure really starts? As we think about kind of anniversary-ing easier comps, did it start middle of last year s
componenttext: Just for clarification -- I'm sorry, one last [indiscernible] When we think about the term versus the spot, when would you say that the term pressure really starts? As we think about kind of anniversary-ing easier comps, did it start middle of last year so that this back half of '16 should have any easier comp relative to last year? Or did it really start to intensify early this year where you'd see kind of an easier comp starting in '17?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we did see it kind of mid last year, the pressure on term contract renewals.
componenttext: No, we did see it kind of mid last year, the pressure on term contract renewals.

componenttext: Yes, good question, Kelly. As you know, there's times when you're precluded from being in the market and times when you can be in the market. But you know us, we'll look at our opportunity set of whether it's acquisitions, buying back stock or whatnot with our cash flow, and we look at that -- the same way always and we'll be prudent with our -- the deployment of our excess cash flow.

componenttext: A lower free cash flow, yes, it's probably going to be in the sort of between $2.10 to maybe $2.35 kind of given where you are depending upon some working capital changes.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just kind of a bigger picture question. Can you help us think about the margin outlook in both the inland and coastal business should these current conditions persist in the back half of the year? And then, specifically, I'm trying to get
componenttext: Okay, great. And just kind of a bigger picture question. Can you help us think about the margin outlook in both the inland and coastal business should these current conditions persist in the back half of the year? And then, specifically, I'm trying to get my head around the operating margin impact of more customers opting for spot versus contracted news on the coastal side.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, clearly pricing has an impact on margins and you would think they will go down. And that's part of what's in our guidance for the third and fourth quarter. Now as utilization starts to come back, we do get a pick up from that. So we think utili
componenttext: Yes. Well, clearly pricing has an impact on margins and you would think they will go down. And that's part of what's in our guidance for the third and fourth quarter. Now as utilization starts to come back, we do get a pick up from that. So we think utilization will come back and most of this is temporary. So it's a balance, but clearly, we've -- and if you look at third and fourth quarter, the margin impact is in our guidance. Now in terms of spot versus contract, the move to more spot actually gives you -- give you some leverage when things start coming back, because you're not locked into lower pricing. A lot of what you're seeing in this pricing environment has just been in the spot market. So very few contracts are being signed up at these low levels.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But more [indiscernible] the spot on the coastal side though. How do we think about -- because you're basically going to have fewer revenue days, and if I'm correct, very similar operating cost. And if it's in a low double-digit range now, so that go to a
componenttext: But more [indiscernible] the spot on the coastal side though. How do we think about -- because you're basically going to have fewer revenue days, and if I'm correct, very similar operating cost. And if it's in a low double-digit range now, so that go to a single-digit range on the coastal side as more customers move over to spot?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It could potentially, yes. Now we're in low double digits now. And clearly, as the spot -- the more spot you have on the coastal side, you just don't get the continuous void. So yes, you don't shed the cost, but you don't have as much revenue. So you're c
componenttext: It could potentially, yes. Now we're in low double digits now. And clearly, as the spot -- the more spot you have on the coastal side, you just don't get the continuous void. So yes, you don't shed the cost, but you don't have as much revenue. So you're correct, it could go into the high single digits.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
