componenttext: And our next question will come from Jack Atkins of Stephens.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, David, just to kind of think about the pricing dynamics on the inland side, I'm looking for -- you talked about unsustainably low spot pricing, which sort of at/or below the breakeven price for some players in the market. Could you give us a s
componenttext: So I guess, David, just to kind of think about the pricing dynamics on the inland side, I'm looking for -- you talked about unsustainably low spot pricing, which sort of at/or below the breakeven price for some players in the market. Could you give us a sense for really where spot rates and contractual rates are today relative to both the prior peak in '14 and then the trough during the recession in '09. So where are we in that continuum with both of those type of rates?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are -- I'm saying from the peak in '14, we're probably down 20%, maybe even 25%. And then from the last downturn, say '09, spot prices are a little below that. Part of that is, frankly, we've got some undisciplined players in the market that have
componenttext: Yes. We are -- I'm saying from the peak in '14, we're probably down 20%, maybe even 25%. And then from the last downturn, say '09, spot prices are a little below that. Part of that is, frankly, we've got some undisciplined players in the market that have impacted it below what was on the last cycle. But yes, that's why we think we're close to the bottom here, because it's hard to envision a very longer -- a longer-term pricing environment where you're at/or below cost -- cash cost. It's not sustainable.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then -- that's helpful. And then, shifting gears over to the diesel engine side, I know a lot of work has been done there to remove excess operating expenses there, just given the type of cycle we've seen in the oilfield services market. B
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then -- that's helpful. And then, shifting gears over to the diesel engine side, I know a lot of work has been done there to remove excess operating expenses there, just given the type of cycle we've seen in the oilfield services market. But as you think about that business potentially recovering in '17, perhaps the second half of '17, I'm curious what you think the land-based margin in the diesel engine services segment could look like over the course of the next cycle? I know, typically, it's been high single digits. With all the cost actions and rationalization in that business for you guys, what is the -- how should we think about that business looking from a profitability perspective coming out of this?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jack, this is Andy. With some of the cost initiatives that we've taken on and some of the improvements that we've made in our processes in that business, we think that we can probably easily add an additional 300 to 400 basis points of margin to that
componenttext: Hey, Jack, this is Andy. With some of the cost initiatives that we've taken on and some of the improvements that we've made in our processes in that business, we think that we can probably easily add an additional 300 to 400 basis points of margin to that business over the next cycle.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Gregory Lewis of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question will come from Gregory Lewis of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, my first question would be around on the inland and the coastal side. Joe mentioned that you guys retired an 80,000-barrel coastal barge earlier this year. As we look at both those markets sort of over the next 12 months in terms of -- what
componenttext: Yes. I guess, my first question would be around on the inland and the coastal side. Joe mentioned that you guys retired an 80,000-barrel coastal barge earlier this year. As we look at both those markets sort of over the next 12 months in terms of -- what visibility have, exclusive of retirements, what type of fleet growth do you expect to see in inland and do you expect to see in coastal?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think -- let me take inland first. Clearly, we're in an oversupplied market right now. We've got too much equipment. And in this kind of market, with this kind of prices, as maintenance decisions come up, certainly, nobody would want to build
componenttext: Yes, well, I think -- let me take inland first. Clearly, we're in an oversupplied market right now. We've got too much equipment. And in this kind of market, with this kind of prices, as maintenance decisions come up, certainly, nobody would want to build into this market right now. No rational player would want to add capacity in this environment. And I think as you look at maintenance decisions that come up on, say, a 25-year-old or 30-year-old barge, you probably tie it up at best and maybe you just retire it and cut it up and sell it for scrap, because at this market, those kind of decisions become easier. And this is why we see, in these kind of environments, the number of retirements go up and the building go down. As we look at the 2017 order book, we're not hearing much at all being let in terms of contracts. So in terms of inland fleet growth, I don't think there will be much, if any, at all, and with retirements, it should contract. On the coastwise side, it's a little more balanced in that you've got some new capacity coming in, including some of ours, over the next to 18 months. I think, in total, it's -- the ones that haven't delivered, maybe it's 14 units. And -- but there are still over 40 units that are 30 years or older in the coastwise business. And they need to come out. And the betting requirements from our customers are getting tougher, and in the offshore environment, they are even tougher than they are in the  inland side. And age is a factor there. So I think you'll see more retirement on the coastwise side. The question is the balance between the new additions in the retirements and how that plays out. But I don't think you'll see overall capacity growth, volume growth on the coastwise side in the barges that are 200,000 and less.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just one other from me. Since the focus it seems like it's going to be on margins. You mentioned the 4 tug barges that you bought for, I don't know, what, $24 million, $25 million and now replacing for older barges. Is -- I'm assumin
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one other from me. Since the focus it seems like it's going to be on margins. You mentioned the 4 tug barges that you bought for, I don't know, what, $24 million, $25 million and now replacing for older barges. Is -- I'm assuming that, that would be margin-accretive. Is there any way to sort of -- I mean, whether it's -- they're more fuel-efficient, whether if they break down less, whether they require more maintenance. Is that enough to sort of move coastal margins a couple basic points or it that more just not -- like not really going to have much of an impact?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably positive. But I'm not sure it's going to move the needle. If you think about it -- and let me clarify, but -- excuse me, 4 tugs not barges. We're retiring 4 40-year-old boats and replacing them with much younger. So what happens is you get a
componenttext: It's probably positive. But I'm not sure it's going to move the needle. If you think about it -- and let me clarify, but -- excuse me, 4 tugs not barges. We're retiring 4 40-year-old boats and replacing them with much younger. So what happens is you get a little more depreciation. But the offset of that is, you get higher reliability, lower maintenance cost and just better utilization out of them. Because there is fewer maintenance days, fewer down days and clearly the younger fleet is more attractive for return customers as well. Now to quantify that in terms of margin, I don't think I can quantify that and I'm not sure it would be that much -- that material. But it certainly is a positive.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So Dave, when you guys talked about the pricing before in terms of the Great Recession, how about utilization? You talked about it dropping to the low to mid-80s. Where did you see utilization getting to -- how low can this go? And then, I guess, i
componenttext: Great. So Dave, when you guys talked about the pricing before in terms of the Great Recession, how about utilization? You talked about it dropping to the low to mid-80s. Where did you see utilization getting to -- how low can this go? And then, I guess, in that utilization concept, you didn't talk much about the remaining crude barges. Is there anything left on that side to still come in -- is that's what creating some of this excess capacity? Are they now all in petrochem? And I guess, sticking with that, a lot of discussion on pricing. But I think on the demand side, anything happened with the new plants. Is there something that's coming on mind that you look out and you see it turn that can drive this?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Let me to take those, try and do them in order. In '09, I think there was a quarter we dipped into the high '70s. But it was, I think, it is just one quarter. So it's not as bad as that, but low 80s is pretty difficult environment in terms of u
componenttext: Yes, sure. Let me to take those, try and do them in order. In '09, I think there was a quarter we dipped into the high '70s. But it was, I think, it is just one quarter. So it's not as bad as that, but low 80s is pretty difficult environment in terms of utilization. In terms of crude barges, I think last quarter we said we estimated there about 175 or so barges still moving crude. And that was down from 550. Our latest poll indicates it's probably around 140 barges. So sure, that did have some impact. It went from 175 down to 140. It's interesting, you'll see, you read some of the snippets that people in the Utica are going to start drilling again. So who knows if we've hit bottom on the crude barges. But clearly, the barges that have come out of crude have been cleaned up and put into clean service, by and large, which has impacted utilization for sure. Now to your broader question about demand. If we look across all of our products that we carry, outside of crude, everything is pretty good. Crude's down for sure. But if you look at the chemicals, they are okay. And we do see continued building. I think one of our customers just announced a new joint venture, they're going to build a new facility on the Gulf Coast. There has been 1 or 2 delays, but, by and large, most of the chemical facilities that have been announced and have started construction are still going on. So that's a positive. Refined products outside of this product let that we're in are now that's impacting kind of some movements. If you look at vehicle miles driven, they are up in refine products demand. It's still growing. I don't think that the production has outpaced it here recently. And that's caused this kind of disruption or product clot, if you will. And then you look at some of the other products. Outside of crude, everything is okay and fairly healthy. It's just we've got a little dislocation now where things have to come back into balance.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, I appreciate that. If I could get a follow-up on the -- your comment on the particular players that are more aggressive. I just want to understand, in that phase, when you're going through this. Your take-or-pay contracts, which kind of are your ba
componenttext: Great, I appreciate that. If I could get a follow-up on the -- your comment on the particular players that are more aggressive. I just want to understand, in that phase, when you're going through this. Your take-or-pay contracts, which kind of are your basis for, I guess, stability or kind of some stability there. What happens to those contracts as they come up for renewal? Do they tend to be higher than average contract pricing and so that's why you see maybe a little bit more volatility? Or is it just anything that gets touched, is just coming down to the current spot levels?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, what you're seeing, because there's equipment availability, some of the term contracts. And this is across the industry, not Kirby-specific. There's some term contracts that aren't getting renewed and they're just going to the spot market for a
componenttext: Yes. Well, what you're seeing, because there's equipment availability, some of the term contracts. And this is across the industry, not Kirby-specific. There's some term contracts that aren't getting renewed and they're just going to the spot market for a while. Now that's not, I don't want to overstate that, that's not a huge number. But there are a number of term contracts that are going to the spot market because the availability is there and that the operators think the shippers aren't as concerned about availability. Now as things start typing up, that will reverse itself and we would expect that to start happening again later this year.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Michael Webber of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Michael Webber of Wells Fargo.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to some of the pricing pressure conversation you're having a bit earlier and maybe kind of backing away from kind of a natural inclination the markets used to have, kind of find a slower, surprising, or kind of setting a bottom. But
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to some of the pricing pressure conversation you're having a bit earlier and maybe kind of backing away from kind of a natural inclination the markets used to have, kind of find a slower, surprising, or kind of setting a bottom. But if I may be -- if we kind of frame this up within the context of the past couple of cycles, you mentioned some of the pricing is unsustainable and ultra-competitive. We're hearing that cash conversion cycles starting to contract. You guys are looking to preserve liquidity. So I guess, maybe, within the context of those past cycles, how long did it take for the market to really clear that capacity and for those irrational actors to actually get removed kind of beyond just the idea of kind of scrapping individual assets. Is that something that's typically measured in quarters or in years when you guys go back and look at the past 2 or 3 or 4 cycles you've been a part of?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, do you want me to take that?
componenttext: David, do you want me to take that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, go ahead with the longest-term contracts.
componenttext: Yes, go ahead with the longest-term contracts.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Having lived through many cycles. The -- well, I think that's it. Firstly, you need to separate what drove the -- some of the cycles in the past have been principally driven by recessions where volumes have declined and you really needed to have a kind of
componenttext: Having lived through many cycles. The -- well, I think that's it. Firstly, you need to separate what drove the -- some of the cycles in the past have been principally driven by recessions where volumes have declined and you really needed to have a kind of a cleansing of the industry. You needed, one, the economy to recover volumes to improve and some equipment to come out. This particular downturn is not economically driven. It's -- it really is affected by a couple of things. It's affected by building barges for a market, the crude oil market that then collapsed as crude oil collapsed. And it's affected by what I think is an anomaly, which is high inventories and the market adjusting to those inventories. We saw something similar to that in 2008 -- end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009 where you did have an economic collapse, but you also had an enormous adjustment in inventories. And that was relatively short. Now there's some other things that are going on, I think, in this particular -- during this particular period. You have the summer weather effect that David talked about. And that's something that we really haven't seen in the last 3 or 4 years because the market's been so tight. There hasn't been enough equipment. But if you go back to the last 30 years before that, you always had utilization drill down in the summer as the system got more efficient and there was more equipment on the market. Come fall, it tightens up again. I think what's happened here is that you have some operators that are already worried about crude oil equipment that don't have a home for it. As any who've had these summer doldrums that have been traditionally seen in the business, and they panicked and they lowered prices just to both equipment, which has dragged the whole market down. As you get some adjustments in inventory, as you go into the fall where the system isn't as efficient, it gets a little less efficient, you'll see utilization get better and I think pricing will follow it. How long it takes to absorb the crude oil overhang, will really be driven by 2 things. One, equipment going out of the market, and some of that is happening now. You're already getting maintenance referrals. So you're going to see less available equipment going forward in the year. And then the volumes that David talked about. You've got strong refined products, markets, record miles driven in the U.S. and I think people are predicting that that's going to continue given that the low gasoline prices. And then you have these volumes that are coming from the chemical business. So it's going to correct itself. I think you'll begin to see it at the end of -- towards the end of the year, and 2017, barring any economic issue, you should see continued correction, higher utilization and more normalcy in pricing.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And just to follow-up on that, Joe. You mentioned kind of petchem cycle potentially starting some point in kind of 17, '18, though when you think about the kind of the enhanced focus around ethane gasoline and kind of away from naphthalene an
componenttext: Fair enough. And just to follow-up on that, Joe. You mentioned kind of petchem cycle potentially starting some point in kind of 17, '18, though when you think about the kind of the enhanced focus around ethane gasoline and kind of away from naphthalene and some of the cargoes, when you think about barge and market share, kind of overall petchem production kind of relative to rail in the pipeline. And when you think about what that mix looks like going forward and yields look like going forward from the petchem space, do you think that barge market share technically grows or just given what we're likely to be.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should grow. Pipelines aren't conducive to the kinds of chemicals that we carry. Barging is much more flexible, because you can source it from different plants. You can move it into different markets. The pipeline is -- you put it in the pipeline, it c
componenttext: It should grow. Pipelines aren't conducive to the kinds of chemicals that we carry. Barging is much more flexible, because you can source it from different plants. You can move it into different markets. The pipeline is -- you put it in the pipeline, it comes out where the pipeline ends. And it also requires steady volumes of some significant nature. That's really not the chemical business. Barging has been the really the principal way of moving chemicals around, because of their flexibility and because of the volumes that you'd typically see. Railroads are competitive depending on where you're moving the chemicals and how much you're moving. You remember that -- the smallest barge that we operate is equal to, I think, 16 railcar. So if you've got more -- you've got less than a barge load than rail makes a lot of sense. If you're taking it to a place that barging doesn't service and rail makes a lot of sense. But typically, most movements, rail is a not a competitive factor. So I would think that we're going to get more than our share.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's a moving target obviously, right. It depends on the share price. So again, on the margin, we do like the acquisitions, but there is a price obviously that our shares are very attractive as well. So it's a balance.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, good. And just sort of a clarification on the history lesson of barge pricing and the utilization. I don't know if you can rattle off the times when you've seen utilization at the low 80s and prices below cash breakeven for some operators, I think you mentioned briefly in '09, have there been some other periods of time that you can recall that happening?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have to almost go back to the 80s where you saw this kind of predatory pricing. In 2001 through 2003, we saw some low prices, but I don't recall of being at cash prices. And we -- I think, David, we have to clarify that not all, not every deal is done
componenttext: You have to almost go back to the 80s where you saw this kind of predatory pricing. In 2001 through 2003, we saw some low prices, but I don't recall of being at cash prices. And we -- I think, David, we have to clarify that not all, not every deal is done this way. It's just that you have several operators that I think have gotten way more nervous than they should be based on some decisions they made with respect to building equipment and then this inventory problem coupled with seasonality that we talked about that. They just panicked. I can't imagine that -- that they're going to carry this forward. Once I see the market improve a little bit, which it really should do just driven by the fact that we're going to be less efficient going into the fall and the winter.

componenttext: Okay, right. And then, I guess, you've got this petchem cycle that's kind of developing. Or is the industry going to underbuild for a couple years where if that cycle really begins to gain some traction, moving back into a much tighter capacity situation when you see, may be experienced a the same type of pricing power we have seen in other cycles. How do you feel about having [indiscernible]

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think it mutes the chemical cycle. If anything, I think what ends up happening is we get some capacity rationalization out of this. And certainly, it should dampen any enthusiasm to build. And I think that's a positive. I think it, for some o
componenttext: Yes. I don't think it mutes the chemical cycle. If anything, I think what ends up happening is we get some capacity rationalization out of this. And certainly, it should dampen any enthusiasm to build. And I think that's a positive. I think it, for some operators that are more highly levered, it really puts them in a tough way, which makes them less likely to go, produce something like build new capacity. So if anything, I don't think this down cycle mutes the benefit from petchem, and if anything, it helps because it is so stinging right now, bring some discipline into the market.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just add one more thing, and, John, I think this is worthy to note. We're down on crude oil because crude oil prices are such that they are some significant restraints to drilling for oil in the U.S. And we tend to think that, that's going to g
componenttext: And let me just add one more thing, and, John, I think this is worthy to note. We're down on crude oil because crude oil prices are such that they are some significant restraints to drilling for oil in the U.S. And we tend to think that, that's going to go on forever, and it's not. I mean, the world's demand for crude oil and the U.S. position, barring some regulations, I don't think we're going to see, is very important to the world oil supply. And we have said this in the past and I think it's worth saying it again, is that barging is going to be one of the ways that you're going to move crude oil to the market. And when the lions come back, you're going to move more volumes of crude oil. And that's also going to have a stabilizing effect on the fleet. I think that Halliburton said the other day in their earnings call that by 2021, the world needed close to 18 million more barrels of oil. That's an enormous amount of oil. And some of that is going to have to come from the U.S. shale effort. And we're going to get some of those lions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will now. We went from an environment where it is all crude oil all the time. So now it's never coming back. I think you've in cycles, I mean, it never goes away permanently, but obviously, there was some overbuilding for a while, I guess. But my l
componenttext: Yes, I will now. We went from an environment where it is all crude oil all the time. So now it's never coming back. I think you've in cycles, I mean, it never goes away permanently, but obviously, there was some overbuilding for a while, I guess. But my last question for you, David, is your comments around the land-based side, diesel engine. When do you think that the inquiries and all on service and reman work starts to resolve in inquiries and orders from the equipment? I mean the rig count is up. [indiscernible] some of the producers are still kind of basically cannibalizing parts and everything from other existing equipment or whatever, but when do you think that load begins to materialize in real orders?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it's interesting, John. I think it's -- because it's been so painful in the pressure pumping business, I think capital there is not as plentiful. And what you're seeing and what we're seeing from our customer base is a lot more reman in service
componenttext: Yes. Well, it's interesting, John. I think it's -- because it's been so painful in the pressure pumping business, I think capital there is not as plentiful. And what you're seeing and what we're seeing from our customer base is a lot more reman in service, almost no discussion about any new capacity. So it's kind of like the reason we said we've get into this business. We thought there would be a lot of reman business, just because capital discipline would work. And I think we're starting to see that play out where we're getting a lot of inquiries about repairing equipment and remanufacturing equipment. Now there's some interesting things going on. We heard some of the oil service commentary that you don't need 1,800 rigs to absorb the pressure pumping fleet. I think it's closer to 900. So that service intensity plus the attrition that's happened in the fleet, so I think on the pressure pumping side, you're going to see that market tighten up pretty quickly. And they need it. I mean, our pressure pumping customers have been cash constrained. So I don't think that's a long way of saying we're not seeing new equipment orders. I don't think -- I mean, they will reemerge, but right now, the demand for [indiscernible] is growing, and to us, it's very encouraging.

componenttext: We still have a volume problem, right. You've got to have enough volume to absorb all your fixed costs. But in general, service margins are usually kind of double digit, whereas, equipment -- new equipment is more high single digits. So yes, service margins should be higher. The issue is, we've got to get to volume where we're absorbing all of our fixed costs, and then the margins will really start to improve.
