headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Let me start with supply. As you know, when spot rates are at or close to break the cash flow breakeven, it's really painful. And what you see in that environment is companies start to accelerate their retirement. They look at some of their old
componenttext: Yes, sure. Let me start with supply. As you know, when spot rates are at or close to break the cash flow breakeven, it's really painful. And what you see in that environment is companies start to accelerate their retirement. They look at some of their older equipment and it's coming up for a shipyard and they say goodness, there is no we were going to spend the cash to extent that life for another 5-year during. So they begin to retire it, and we're starting to see some aggressive retirement. So I think the last time we talked, we were talking about Kirby's retirements around 39 barges this year. I think will probably end up with about 54 retire this year. So we're retiring more barges, the industry is regarding more barges and it's just a matter of good economic discipline and stewardship. Some of our competitors don't have the economic wherewithal to actually make the investment to extend the lives, so they are almost forced to retire. So we think we'll see a good number of retirements this year and that's happening now and it should carry into next year. I think, the order of magnitude I think, in past histories, we've seen up to 150 to 2200 barges retired in 1 year. If you think about our digitization being somewhere right now between 80% and 85%, maybe closer to 85%. Your 5% from kind of the high 80s where you need price increases. So 5% of the industry is probably around a little less than 300 barges and maybe 250. And if you get some retirements that, that will get the utilization up without any demand growth. Now we do have demand growth, which I'll come back to in a minute. On the shipyard side, the new construction basically it's nonexistent. There may be a handful of barges, as you heard Andy's prepared comments, we shifted some barges that we're going to deliver this year into next year. So I think it's probably a handful of barges to get built next year, maybe 2 handfuls. But so from a surprise standpoint, it looks pretty good. On the demand standpoint, we still have pretty good market outside of crude oil. If you look at chemicals, everybody knows that chemicals continue to increase, albeit, at the construction of all the new plant is probably a bigger impact in 2018 because those projects tend to flip to the right, as you know. But in refined products, black oil, all those, the macroeconomic trends are fairly positive. YOu can look at vehicle miles driven. They continue to grow albeit at a slower pace your of fleet. But the general demand picture is pretty good. So I think demand will also require some more barges. I think utilization in the industry is maybe a little low because we've had some inventory disruptions and some bloated inventories and frankly, we've had really good weather. You can look at the delayed days and see that. They're very, very much lower than normal. So from a soup why demand standpoint, I think, things should come into balance in 2017. And that will drive pricing. These spot contracts are pretty brutal right now. And frankly, they aren't sustainably low. Now with respect to earnings, I mean, you've heard us say this before. We have contracts that rollover kind of ratably through the year. And as they roll over at lower prices, that has a full year effect after -- in the next year. So that will be an impact as all -- as the contracts essentially renewed lower this year. There will be a full year effect next year. I think that's not a surprise to anybody but it's just a matter of math. I don't know if that answered your question but [indiscernible] this one.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, incredibly thorough. So that sounds like the opportunity. And then just for my follow-up on the risk side with coastal, what's the potential or how much more could potentially move to spot? What's the risk for, I guess, a very precipitous decline in t
componenttext: No, incredibly thorough. So that sounds like the opportunity. And then just for my follow-up on the risk side with coastal, what's the potential or how much more could potentially move to spot? What's the risk for, I guess, a very precipitous decline in the emirate market to kind of cannibalize your cargoes. And and hope much more can you to rightsize the cost structure in the coastal business if the demand side were to be pressured next year?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in the coastal market, it is as we've been saying, we've got a situation where you've got new tonnage coming in. I think there's about 14 new units that will be delivered in the next 18 months-or-so. Brand-new ADB barge units coming into the market.
componenttext: Yes, in the coastal market, it is as we've been saying, we've got a situation where you've got new tonnage coming in. I think there's about 14 new units that will be delivered in the next 18 months-or-so. Brand-new ADB barge units coming into the market. And there are probably around 40 older barges that are at retirement age or be actually probably been extended longer than they should that didn't to come out of the market. But as you know, you work older tonnage as long as you can until you can't. So there has to be a little pain to drive that older tonnage out. I think, it's starting to happen. I think it will happen and may take a couple of years to play out as that access -- access the do you equipments absorbed in the older tonnage comes out. We have seen because of the axis come been that customers are not too worried about having of the in a bit the. So there's been a drift towards taking chance in the spot market. Clearly, the spot market is more difficult for us. You get periods of lower utilization because of it repositioning barges, it's on our nickel in that case. So it's a bit painful. You see that you saw our brand is comes in our margins there work but I think, the longer term, it will come back into balance because of that old tonnage has to come out and will come out as you come into the shipyard. And, as you know, the shipyards for these coastal units are very much more expensive than the inland one. So there's a natural tension that should encourage retirement.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Gregory Lewis of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll open this up to either David or Joe. And really my question is clearly, Kirby has always been in the market looking at M&A transactions. But just as we've looked through previous periods of time, I mean, you guys have alluded to the fact that
componenttext: I guess I'll open this up to either David or Joe. And really my question is clearly, Kirby has always been in the market looking at M&A transactions. But just as we've looked through previous periods of time, I mean, you guys have alluded to the fact that the market is kind of at the bottom. Do we need to see the market start to improve before maybe we can see a pickup in M&A or can we sort of down cycle-ish type acquisitions?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me give a quick comment and I'll turn it over to Joe to give his comments. The -- nobody wants to sell that the bottom right, Greg? You don't want to sell out at the bottom. You want to maximize your price if you're a seller and then that's norma
componenttext: Yes, let me give a quick comment and I'll turn it over to Joe to give his comments. The -- nobody wants to sell that the bottom right, Greg? You don't want to sell out at the bottom. You want to maximize your price if you're a seller and then that's normal. I think there are some people in the market that in this environment, if you add had levered up at 4x EBITDA and things were really good back in 2012, '13 and we've -- you see this kind of announced downturn that we've had. Those debt to EBITDA multiples get really stretched and there may be some people in trouble. Hard to say we don't have insight to their financials because a good many of them are private. But by and large, I would say that nobody would like to sell at the bottom. But some people may be feel like that it's still time to sell. I'll turn it over to Joe. He's got a lot more history on how these cycles play out.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David has it about the right. The kind of sales that you would see here is either a company that owns a barging business in addition to something else that we want to deploy capital. So let's sell the barge operation. You saw that with respect Sica r
componenttext: Yes, David has it about the right. The kind of sales that you would see here is either a company that owns a barging business in addition to something else that we want to deploy capital. So let's sell the barge operation. You saw that with respect Sica recently and you may see some of that in the next year. The 4 sales are typically bank driven and we'll just have to wait and see, if any of that happens. What David is talking about are really operators that go through the cycle that's painful. They realize that they're vulnerable, they're getting into the point in their lives that they're getting thinking about doing other things. And they're just looking for opportunity to capture some additional value that may not be there at the bottom of the cycle. So if you look at Kirby's historical acquisitions, they typically have heard as we came out of a recession, not in the middle of it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just David, your comments on the services and you kind of give some guidance. When could we see we and I guess what needs to happen for this diesel engine services on the line side to get back to breakeven? It seems like we're kind o
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just David, your comments on the services and you kind of give some guidance. When could we see we and I guess what needs to happen for this diesel engine services on the line side to get back to breakeven? It seems like we're kind of in that period of where we're getting there. I mean, it sounds -- I mean, any sort of guidance you can give around that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're getting closer everyday. Let me characterize it this way, Greg, our customers in the number of the we have in the shop for service are growing everyday. It's a bigger number. But the initial wave of [ph], if you will, are customers that are co
componenttext: Sure. We're getting closer everyday. Let me characterize it this way, Greg, our customers in the number of the we have in the shop for service are growing everyday. It's a bigger number. But the initial wave of [ph], if you will, are customers that are coming with kind of their better fleets that just needs some maintenance or they think it's easy to fix to get it running again. And they say, okay, they bring it in and let's just get it running. And by the way, if you have any major components that the to be ripped the stores some parts that need to be ripped ways, these use our inventory for store they demand that we used their inventory first. They have have extra spares and stuff. So even though we're getting an increasing amounts of remands, the parts and rebuild componentry that goes with normal remands is still developing as our customers work of their own inventories first. But everyday, we're getting closer to working that off and I think, you'll start to see us get parts and major component flow through, which will add to our ability to absorb fixed cost and be above breakeven. We're getting closer everyday and the signs are very encouraging from what we're seeing. Our customers are coming to us with very large fleets, trying to get them back into service. They are, of course, the still coming out of the bottom, so they are trying to minimize their spend at this point. We are working with our customers to help them do that, get their service going and build a long-term supply chain maintenance partnership. And that's happening very, very well. We're pretty excited about it.

And splitting that down, about 50% of it is term contracts and 20% of it is spot and the spot obviously is pretty quick and it's sort of irritable throughout the year. And the term contracts, I would say, for the most part, in any given year, are pretty ratable as well. I wouldn't say that we favor 1 quarter to another in terms of what reprices.

componenttext: I'll start and then I'm going to turn over to Andy to maybe quantify it a bit. But as you know pricing is almost a direct hit to margin, right? I mean, as pricing falls, it does impact margin pretty quickly. Right away on spot and then it contracts, it takes a while to roll through from a full year effect. But utilization also has a pretty big impact. You can see if you look at our second quarter of this year and third quarter, we had a decline across the board and utilization on the inland side that was on the order of 5% to 10%. And I mean you could see, if you look at the core -- the sequential decline from second quarter to third quarter, how that utilization has a pretty big drive in terms of earnings power. Andy, anything you can add?

componenttext: Well, john, I would split that the us I would split my answer on the inland side and goes all said before the inland side, I would say that when you see utility fall, because of the way that we manage our horsepower, we do have some levers we can pull and we did in the third quarter. Now they're not immediate but overtime, we were able to get rid of some charter boats and some caused so us is a margins photo the inland side, they don't fall necessarily sort of dollar for dollar with the fall the activity as the revenue impact of the fall of the utility. On the coastwise side, as you see pieces of equipment move from term contracts to spot business, where they are best but if you guys pretty that it'd be because general you're talking about 1 piece of horsepower to 1 barge, that utility kind of falls pretty dramatically to the bottom line. So you can see the impact of utility on the coastwise side being a little bit more significant in your margin than that you see it on the inland side.

componenttext: Yes, so my question pertains to I guess 2017. And David, in your commentary, you gave very good guidance indivisibility as far as your current utilization levels are and why you expect them to increase into the mid-80% range heading into next year. And clearly, there's a lot of debate about the timing of the pet chem ramp up next year, the order of margin of of how much of that stuff comes in the barge. So my question is trying to get visibility about impact of utilization levels next year of that which clearly that habit of always out what I would imagine you guys are having conversations at this point with some of your petrochemical customers about some of the other barge needs are for next year. So based on those conversation and obviously without getting specific can you help us frame we should expect a decision level evolve next year if you're heading into 2017 in the mid-80% range, how we should expect utilization levels to evolve and what type of levels we could possibly hit next year?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take that in pieces here. I think a big part of the utilization drop off we've seen in the third quarter has been temporary in nature. One, as we said, the delayed days are very low with good weather, dock delays have been down considerably. T
componenttext: Yes, let me take that in pieces here. I think a big part of the utilization drop off we've seen in the third quarter has been temporary in nature. One, as we said, the delayed days are very low with good weather, dock delays have been down considerably. The number of locks and dams that were under repair and slowing things down was minimal. So that temporary type utilization will come back, and we're going to have that whether in the fourth quarter. We always do. We've had some refinery inventory issues. I think that's self-correcting now. We're in the refinery maintenance season. So inventory are kind the right size and things will get back into a more normal flow of things. So some of those temporary utilization things will come back. It's maybe into the fourth quarter and to early part of '17. I think, the longer-term utilization will come, as we talked about earlier, the supply coming out and no new supply coming in the retirement. And then I think, you get towards the end of '17 and early '18 before you start to see the chemical buildout and start out of plans having an impact. We are in discussions with many of our customers about their needs there it's still that way us out but it's going to start probably towards the end of '17. I wouldn't hazard a guess to the actual number of the barges as a percent utilization. We do know -- look, if it's in the ethylene plant, as a nascent driven activated time to go into port after that, we'll there's not a lot of barge moves. But if it goes from ethane to ethylene and then to some downstream derivatives, whether it's glycol or BBC or whatnot, there can be a significant number of barges. A lot of that still being held closely to the best day of our customers, for trade secret reasons. We're getting a field for it, some are very abundant and orders are pretty quiet about it. But again, I think, that's late '17 and the bulk of the ethylene startups will be in '18.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a possibility. We've always said this that crude is best moved in a pipeline and that sort to ype lend a. I do think what you're seeing now portends that you will see more crude volumes coming out of the showplace. We know that's going
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a possibility. We've always said this that crude is best moved in a pipeline and that sort to ype lend a. I do think what you're seeing now portends that you will see more crude volumes coming out of the showplace. We know that's going to have them but ultimately, it will end up in a pipeline. We could get some demand from the jail place if things continue to improve. But it's not something that we think is should be that. We wouldn't bet a bunch of it with that on. If it helps that, that it up, that would be great. I mean we saw what you they did in 2012 to 2014. But then that overhang is what we're dealing with now. I would say this, the number of barges moving crude right now is roughly the same as it was last quarter, right around 140 barges so it seems to have stabilized. But long-term trend is crude should be moved in a pipeline I think, part of the problem with fuel pipelines coming on is they're going want to 20-year offtake agreements. So there is that an area where you could see some of barge volume comeback. It's not something that we're betting on now.

componenttext: David, just want to go back to a couple of your earlier comments. I guess 1 on rationalization and in following up on margins. I think you mentioned 2017 being potential inflection point and saying some of the older capacity come out to the market and helping you define balance in terms of pricing. I guess my question is to what degree of confidence do you have in 2017 being that period. If we look across most of the marine spaces and even host code we still see 45-year-old ATBs are trading in the market that have gone 2 or 3 cycles. So it seems like takes a bit the word and kind of 12 months rationalization peer you would look so I am curious how you think about that on the end of time than what great confidence you have in 2017 versus '18 or '19?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think your comments are generally correct. On the inland side, rationalization can happen a lot quicker. It's really easy to take out 10,000-barrel barge. It's lower capital account. It's easier to find support or to cut them up and sell them for s
componenttext: Yes, I think your comments are generally correct. On the inland side, rationalization can happen a lot quicker. It's really easy to take out 10,000-barrel barge. It's lower capital account. It's easier to find support or to cut them up and sell them for scrap. Your point is taking on the ATBs, these are bigger units, there's a higher capital base and if you can keep them working in their long in the tooth, they're fully depreciated. It's a pretty good deal terms of that has to be paid for them in order to take them out. And that's why I said in the coastal side, it could take a couple of years for that to layout us of those 14 new ones come in and the 40 come out. Now on the inland side, as you have seen, we often just in the last since our last call from plant retirants and inland of 39 to 54 this year alone. So yes, it's a pretty direct economic question took to the operator and you can rationalize pretty quick. So I think you'll see pretty hefty retirements in the inland side.

componenttext: Yes, well David, we certainly like our stock at these prices and if we bought it at higher levels, you can imagine we like them at these lower levels. I would say this though, our -- one of our first priorities in terms of capital deployment is a consolidating acquisition in our core businesses. And clearly, we like to do that. It sets the company up for long-term growth. So that tends to get the higher priority. And you can to be in the market buying back stock. If you're looking at material acquisitions and even if you don't know whether they're going to happen or not. And so I think that's understood. There's times when you can be in the market and times when you can't. But we're glad we've got the balance sheet we do. As you saw, we're down 23% at the total cap. That's a good position to be in and in a market like his. We're -- this is where our capital discipline in our financial strength become a pretty good strategic tool.
